{{For|the years 600|600s BC (decade)|600s (disambiguation){{!}}600s|600}}
{{Infobox number
| number = 600
| divisor = 1, 2, 3, 4, 5, 6, 8, 10, 12, 15, 20, 24, 25, 30, 40, 50, 60, 75, 100, 120, 150, 200, 300, 600
}}

'''600''' ('''six hundred''') is the [[natural number]] following [[500 (number)#590s|599]] and preceding [[#600s|601]].
{{TOC limit|3}}

==Mathematical properties==
Six hundred is a [[composite number]], an [[abundant number]], a [[pronic number]]<ref name=":0">{{Cite web|url=https://oeis.org/A002378|title=Sloane's A002378 : Oblong (or promic, pronic, or heteromecic) numbers|website=The On-Line Encyclopedia of Integer Sequences|publisher=OEIS Foundation|access-date=2016-06-11}}</ref> and a [[Harshad number]].

==In other fields==
* In the United States, a [[credit score]] of 600 or below is considered a poor score, thus limiting available credit (or requiring the borrower to pay higher interest rates).
* 600 is the advertised number of miles that [[NASCAR]] runs in the [[Coca-Cola 600]], the longest race on any of the NASCAR circuits.
* [[Fiat 600]]
* In [[Latin language|Latin]], ''sescenti'' often denoted a [[Indefinite and fictitious numbers|very large but indefinite number]], perhaps from the size of a Roman [[Cohort (military unit)|cohort]].<ref>Lewis and Short, ''[[A Latin Dictionary]]'', ''s.v.'' ''[http://www.perseus.tufts.edu/hopper/text?doc=Perseus%3Atext%3A1999.04.0059%3Aentry%3Dsescenti sescenti]''</ref>

==Integers from 601 to 699==

===600s===
* 601 = prime number, [[centered pentagonal number]]<ref name=":1">{{Cite web|url=https://oeis.org/A005891|title=Sloane's A005891 : Centered pentagonal numbers|website=The On-Line Encyclopedia of Integer Sequences|publisher=OEIS Foundation|access-date=2016-06-11}}</ref>
* 602 = 2 × 7 × 43, [[nontotient]], area code for [[Phoenix, AZ]] along with [[area code 480|480]] and [[area code 623|623]]
* 603 = 3<sup>2</sup> × 67, [[Harshad number]], area code for [[New Hampshire]]
* 604 = 2<sup>2</sup> × 151, [[nontotient]], totient sum for first 44 integers, area code for southwestern British Columbia (Lower Mainland, Fraser Valley, Sunshine Coast and Sea to Sky)
* 605 = 5 × 11<sup>2</sup>, [[Harshad number]]
* 606 = 2 × 3 × 101, [[sphenic number]], sum of six consecutive primes (89 + 97 + 101 + 103 + 107 + 109)
* 607 – prime number, sum of three consecutive primes (197 + 199 + 211), [[Mertens function]](607) = 0, [[balanced prime]],<ref name=":2">{{Cite web|url=https://oeis.org/A006562|title=Sloane's A006562 : Balanced primes|website=The On-Line Encyclopedia of Integer Sequences|publisher=OEIS Foundation|access-date=2016-06-11}}</ref> strictly non-palindromic number<ref name=":3">{{Cite web|url=https://oeis.org/A016038|title=Sloane's A016038 : Strictly non-palindromic numbers|website=The On-Line Encyclopedia of Integer Sequences|publisher=OEIS Foundation|access-date=2016-06-11}}</ref>
* 608 = 2<sup>5</sup> × 19, [[Mertens function]](608) = 0, [[nontotient]], [[happy number]]
* 609 = 3 × 7 × 29, [[sphenic number]]

===610s===
* 610 = 2 × 5 × 61, sphenic number, [[nontotient]], [[Fibonacci number]],<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://oeis.org/A000045|title=Sloane's A000045 : Fibonacci numbers|website=The On-Line Encyclopedia of Integer Sequences|publisher=OEIS Foundation|access-date=2016-06-11}}</ref> [[Markov number]].<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://oeis.org/A002559|title=Sloane's A002559 : Markoff (or Markov) numbers|website=The On-Line Encyclopedia of Integer Sequences|publisher=OEIS Foundation|access-date=2016-06-11}}</ref> Also a kind of [[610 (telephone)|telephone wall socket]] used in [[Australia]].
* 611 = 13 × 47, sum of the three standard board sizes in Go (9<sup>2</sup> + 13<sup>2</sup> + 19<sup>2</sup>)
* 612 = 2<sup>2</sup> × 3<sup>2</sup> × 17, [[Harshad number]], area code for [[Area code 612|Minneapolis, MN]]

{{Main|613 (number)}}
* 613 = prime number, first number of [[prime triple]] (''p'', ''p'' + 4, ''p'' + 6), middle number of [[sexy prime]] triple (''p'' − 6, ''p'', ''p'' + 6). Geometrical numbers:  [[Centered square number]] with 18 per side, [[circular number]] of 21 with a square grid and 27 using a triangular grid.  Also 17-gonal.  Hypotenuse of a right triangle with integral sides, these being 35 and 612.  Partitioning:  613 partitions of 47 into non-factor primes, 613 non-squashing partitions into distinct parts of the number 54.  Squares:  Sum of squares of two consecutive integers, 17 and 18.  Additional properties:  a [[lucky number]].
** In [[Judaism]] the number 613 is very significant, as its metaphysics, the [[Kabbalah]], views every complete entity as divisible into 613 parts:  613 parts of every [[Sefirah]]; [[613 mitzvot]], or divine [[613 mitzvot|Commandments]] in the [[Torah]]; 613 parts of the human body.
** The number 613 hangs from the rafters at [[Madison Square Garden]] in honor of legendary [[New York Knicks]] coach [[Red Holzman]]'s 613 victories.
* 614 = 2 × 307, [[nontotient]]. According to Rabbi [[Emil Fackenheim]], the number of Commandments in Judaism should be 614 rather than the traditional 613.
* 615 = 3 × 5 × 41, [[sphenic number]]

{{Main|616 (number)}}
* 616 = 2<sup>3</sup> × 7 × 11, [[Padovan sequence|Padovan number]], an alternative value for the [[Number of the Beast (numerology)|Number of the Beast]] (more commonly accepted to be [[666 (number)|666]]).
* 617 = prime number, sum of five consecutive primes (109 + 113 + 127 + 131 + 137), [[Chen prime]], [[Eisenstein prime]] with no imaginary part
** [[Area codes 617 and 857|Area code 617]], a telephone area code covering the metropolitan Boston area.
* 618 = 2 × 3 × 103, [[sphenic number]].
* 619 = prime number, [[strobogrammatic prime]],<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://oeis.org/A007597|title=Sloane's A007597 : Strobogrammatic primes|website=The On-Line Encyclopedia of Integer Sequences|publisher=OEIS Foundation|access-date=2016-06-11}}</ref> [[alternating factorial]]<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://oeis.org/A005165|title=Sloane's A005165 : Alternating factorials|website=The On-Line Encyclopedia of Integer Sequences|publisher=OEIS Foundation|access-date=2016-06-11}}</ref>

===620s===
* 620 = 2<sup>2</sup> × 5 × 31, sum of four consecutive primes (149 + 151 + 157 + 163), sum of eight consecutive primes (61 + 67 + 71 + 73 + 79 + 83 + 89 + 97). The sum of the first 620 primes is itself prime.<ref>{{oeis|A013916}}</ref>
* 621 = 3<sup>3</sup> × 23, Harshad number
* 622 = 2 × 311, [[nontotient]]. It is also the standard diameter of modern road [[bicycle wheel]]s (622 mm, from hook bead to hook bead)
* 623 = 7 × 89
* 624 = 2<sup>4</sup> × 3 × 13, sum of a twin prime (311 + 313), Harshad number, Zuckerman number
* 625 = 5<sup>4</sup> = 25<sup>2</sup>, sum of seven consecutive primes (73 + 79 + 83 + 89 + 97 + 101 + 103), [[centered octagonal number]],<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://oeis.org/A016754|title=Sloane's A016754 : Odd squares: a(n) = (2n+1)^2. Also centered octagonal numbers|website=The On-Line Encyclopedia of Integer Sequences|publisher=OEIS Foundation|access-date=2016-06-11}}</ref> 1-[[automorphic number]], [[Friedman number]] since 625 = 5<sup>6−2</sup><ref name=":4">{{Cite web|url=https://oeis.org/A036057|title=Sloane's A036057 : Friedman numbers|website=The On-Line Encyclopedia of Integer Sequences|publisher=OEIS Foundation|access-date=2016-06-11}}</ref>
* 626 = 2 × 313, [[nontotient]]
* 627 = 3 × 11 × 19, sphenic number, number of integer [[partition (number theory)|partitions]] of 20,<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://oeis.org/A000041|title=Sloane's A000041 : a(n) = number of partitions of n|website=The On-Line Encyclopedia of Integer Sequences|publisher=OEIS Foundation|access-date=2016-06-11}}</ref> [[Smith number]]<ref name=":5">{{Cite web|url=https://oeis.org/A006753|title=Sloane's A006753 : Smith numbers|website=The On-Line Encyclopedia of Integer Sequences|publisher=OEIS Foundation|access-date=2016-06-11}}</ref>
* 628 = 2<sup>2</sup> × 157, [[nontotient]], totient sum for first 45 integers
* 629 = 17 × 37, [[highly cototient number]],<ref name=":6">{{Cite web|url=https://oeis.org/A100827|title=Sloane's A100827 : Highly cototient numbers|website=The On-Line Encyclopedia of Integer Sequences|publisher=OEIS Foundation|access-date=2016-06-11}}</ref> Harshad number

===630s===
* 630 = 2 × 3<sup>2</sup> × 5 × 7, sum of six consecutive primes (97 + 101 + 103 + 107 + 109 + 113), [[triangular number]], [[hexagonal number]],<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://oeis.org/A000384|title=Sloane's A000384 : Hexagonal numbers|website=The On-Line Encyclopedia of Integer Sequences|publisher=OEIS Foundation|access-date=2016-06-11}}</ref> [[sparsely totient number]],<ref name=":7">{{Cite web|url=https://oeis.org/A036913|title=Sloane's A036913 : Sparsely totient numbers|website=The On-Line Encyclopedia of Integer Sequences|publisher=OEIS Foundatioin|access-date=2016-06-11}}</ref> Harshad number
* 631 = prime number, [[centered triangular number]],<ref name=":8">{{Cite web|url=https://oeis.org/A005448|title=Sloane's A005448 : Centered triangular numbers|website=The On-Line Encyclopedia of Integer Sequences|publisher=OEIS Foundation|access-date=2016-06-11}}</ref> [[centered hexagonal number]],<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://oeis.org/A003215|title=Sloane's A003215 : Hex (or centered hexagonal) numbers|website=The On-Line Encyclopedia of Integer Sequences|publisher=OEIS Foundation|access-date=2016-06-11}}</ref> Chen prime; (other fields) {{anchor|631 other fields}}the number of seats in [[Bundestag]]

* 636 = 2<sup>2</sup> × 3 × 53, sum of ten consecutive primes (43 + 47 + 53 + 59 + 61 + 67 + 71 + 73 + 79 + 83), Smith number,<ref name=":5" /> Mertens function(636) = 0,

* 639 = 3<sup>2</sup> × 71, sum of the first twenty primes, also [[ISO 639]] is the [[International Organization for Standardization|ISO]]'s standard for codes for the representation of [[language]]s

* 640 = 2<sup>7</sup> × 5, Harshad number, number of acres in a square mile

* 651 = 3 × 7 × 31, sphenic number, [[pentagonal number]],<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://oeis.org/A000326|title=Sloane's A000326 : Pentagonal numbers|website=The On-Line Encyclopedia of Integer Sequences|publisher=OEIS Foundation|access-date=2016-06-11}}</ref> [[nonagonal number]]<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://oeis.org/A001106|title=Sloane's A001106 : 9-gonal (or enneagonal or nonagonal) numbers|website=The On-Line Encyclopedia of Integer Sequences|publisher=OEIS Foundation|access-date=2016-06-11}}</ref>

* 655 = 5 × 131
* 656 = 2<sup>4</sup> × 41. In [[Judaism]], 656 is the number of times that [[Jerusalem]] is mentioned in the [[Hebrew Bible]] or [[Old Testament]]. 
* 657 = 3<sup>2</sup> × 73, the largest known number not of the form ''a''<sup>2</sup>+''s'' with ''s'' a [[semiprime]]
* 658 = 2 × 7 × 47, sphenic number

* 664 = 2<sup>3</sup> × 83
Country calling code for Montserrat (+1) 664

The code for international direct dial phone calls to [[Kiribati]].

[[Strobogrammatic number]]<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://oeis.org/A000787|title=Sloane's A000787 : Strobogrammatic numbers|website=The On-Line Encyclopedia of Integer Sequences|publisher=OEIS Foundation|access-date=2016-06-11}}</ref>

pages.title: 613 (number)
pages.text:
{{Infobox number
| number = 613
| prime = yes
}}
'''613''' ('''six hundred [and] thirteen''') is the [[natural number]] following [[600 (number)#610s|612]] and preceding [[600 (number)#610s|614]].

==Mathematical properties==
613 is a [[prime number]], the first number of [[prime triplet]] (''p'', ''p'' + 4, ''p'' + 6), middle number of [[sexy prime]] triple (''p'' − 6, ''p'', ''p'' + 6). It is the index of a prime [[Lucas number]].<ref>[http://www2.stetson.edu/~efriedma/numbers.html What's Special About This Number?]</ref>

613 is a [[centered square number]] with 18 per side, a [[circular number]] of 21 with a square grid and 27 using a triangular grid.  It is also 17-gonal.

613 is the sum of squares of two consecutive integers, 17 and 18, and is also a [[lucky number]] and thus a lucky prime.

==Other occurrences==
The [[613 commandments]] ({{lang-he|תרי"ג מצוות}}: ''taryag mitzvot'', "613 Mitzvot") - 613 is the number of [[mitzvot]] in the Jewish [[Torah]].

In [[Judaism|Jewish]] [[Kabbalah]] the number 613 is very significant, every complete entity is seen as being divisible into 613 parts:  613 parts of every [[Sefirah]]; 613 parts of divine mitzvot in the Torah; 613 parts of the human body. 

The pomegranate is said in Judaism to have 613 seeds.

The number 613 hangs from the rafters at [[Madison Square Garden]] in honor of legendary [[New York Knicks]] coach [[Red Holzman]]'s 613 victories.{{importance inline}}{{cn|date=February 2018}}

The [[Beatles]] mentioned "love" in their lyrics 613 times.<ref>[https://www.theguardian.com/music/datablog/2010/nov/16/beatles-lyrics-words-music-itunes Beatles lyrics and the words they used most]</ref>{{importance-inline}}

In ''[[Scandal (TV series)|Scandal]]'', the secret agency is known as B613.

==See also==
* The years [[613]] and [[613 BC]]
* [[List of highways numbered 613]]
* The [[asteroid]] [[613 Ginevra]]
* [[United Nations Security Council Resolution 613]]

pages.title: 616 (number)
pages.text:
{{Infobox number
| number = 616
}}
'''616''' ('''six hundred [and] sixteen''') is the [[natural number]] following [[600 (number)#610s|615]] and preceding [[600 (number)#610s|617]].

While [[666 (number)|666]] is called the "[[number of the beast]]" in most manuscripts of [[Book of Revelation|Revelation]] {{bibleverse-nb||Revelation|13:18|}},<ref name="Beale, 718">“…a copyist may have intentionally changed the number to 616 under influence from the Latin form of the name Nero, which, transcribed into Hebrew characters…, produces 616.” ({{harvnb|Beale|1999|p = 718|ISBN = 9780802821744}})</ref> a fragment of the earliest [[papyrus 115]] gives the number as 616.<ref name = "beast" />

==In mathematics==
616 is a member of the [[Padovan sequence]], coming after 265, 351, 465 (it is the sum of the first two of these).<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://oeis.org/A000931|title=Sloane's A000931 : Padovan sequence|website=The On-Line Encyclopedia of Integer Sequences|publisher=OEIS Foundation|access-date=2016-06-02}}</ref> 616 is a [[polygonal number]] in four different ways: it is a [[heptagonal number]], as well as 13-, 31- and 104-gonal.

It is also the sum of the [[Square (algebra)|squares]] of the [[factorials]] of 2,3,4. i.e. (2!)² + (3!)² + (4!)² = 4+36+576=616.

==The Number of the Beast==
{{Main article|Number of the Beast}}
666 is generally believed to have been the original [[Number of the Beast]] in the [[Book of Revelation]] in the [[Christianity|Christian]] [[Bible]].<ref>{{Cite web |url=http://news.nationalgeographic.com/news/2005/04/0425_050425_papyrus.html |title=Papyrus Reveals New Clues to Ancient World |access-date=2011-11-21 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120116055855/http://news.nationalgeographic.com/news/2005/04/0425_050425_papyrus.html |archive-date=2012-01-16 |dead-url=yes |df= }}</ref> In 2005, however, a fragment of [[papyrus 115]] was revealed, containing the earliest known version of that part of the Book of Revelation discussing the Number of the Beast. It gave the number as 616, suggesting that this may have been the original.<ref name = "beast">[http://www.csad.ox.ac.uk/POxy/beast616.htm The Other Number of the Beast]</ref>  One possible explanation for the two different numbers is that they reflect two different spellings of Emperor [[Nero]]/Neron's name, for which (according to this theory) this number is believed to be a code.<ref>[https://oyc.yale.edu/religious-studies/rlst-152/lecture-23 Prof Dale Martin's Lecture 23 - "Apocalyptic and Resistance" (from "Introduction to the New Testament History and Literature", RLST 152)]</ref><ref>[https://www.numberphile.com/videos/evil-number?rq=666 666 - professors explain Roulette and Nero in detail; numberphile.com]</ref>  However, other scholars state that the number cannot represent Nero.<ref>[http://www.csad.ox.ac.uk/POxy/numero.htm Numerology of the Beast (Centre for the Study of Ancient Documents, Oxford)]</ref>

==In other fields==
* [[Earth-616]] is the name used to identify the primary [[continuity (fiction)|continuity]] in which most [[Marvel Comics]]' titles take place.
* [[616 film]], a medium film format.
* [[Area code 616]], an area code in [[Michigan]].

pages.title: 666 (number)
pages.text:
{{for|the year 666 AD|666}} {{Infobox number | number = 666 | lang2 = [[Chinese numeral]] | lang2 symbol = 六百六十六 | lang3 = [[Arabic numeral]] | lang3 symbol = ٦٦٦ |Greek prefix=ἑξακόσιοι ἑξήκοντα ἕξ
hexakósioi hexēkonta héx|Latin prefix=sescenti sexaginta sex}} '''666''' ('''six hundred [and] sixty-six''') is the [[natural number]] following [[600 (number)#660s|665]] and preceding [[600 (number)#660s|667]]. 666 is called the "[[number of the Beast]]" in (most manuscripts of) chapter {{bibleverse-nb||Revelation|13|niv}} of the [[Book of Revelation]], of the [[New Testament]],Beale, Gregory K. (1999). The Book of Revelation: A Commentary on the Greek Text. Grand Rapids, Michigan: Wm. B. Eerdmans Publishing. p. 718. {{ISBN|080282174X}}. Retrieved 9 July 2012. and also in popular culture. == In mathematics == 666 is the sum of the first 36 [[natural numbers]] (\sum_{i=1}^{36} i, i.e. {{nowrap|1=1 + 2 + 3 + ... + 34 + 35 + 36 = 666}}), and thus it is a [[triangular number]]. Notice that {{nowrap|1=36 = 15 + 21}}; 15, 21, and 36 are also triangular numbers; and {{nowrap|1=152 + 212 = 225 + 441 = 666}}. In [[radix|base 10]], 666 is a [[repdigit]] (and therefore a [[palindromic number]]) and a [[Smith number]]. A [[prime reciprocal magic square]] based on 1/149 in base 10 has a magic total of 666. The prime factorization of 666 is 2 • 32 • 37. Also, 666 is the sum of squares of first seven primes: 2^2 + 3^2 + 5^2 + 7^2 + 11^2 + 13^2 + 17^2 The [[Roman numeral]] for 666, DCLXVI, has exactly one occurrence of all symbols whose value is less than 1000 in decreasing order (D = 500, C = 100, L = 50, X = 10, V = 5, I = 1). == In religion == === Number of the Beast === [[Image:DVinfernoLuciferKingOfHell m.jpg|thumb|right|222px|666 is often associated with the [[devil]].]] {{Main|Number of the Beast}} In the [[Textus Receptus]] manuscripts of the [[New Testament]], the [[Book of Revelation]] ({{bibleverse-nb||Revelation|13:17–18|}}) cryptically asserts 666 to be "man's number" or "the number of a man" (depending on how the text is translated) associated with [[The Beast (Revelation)|the Beast]], an antagonistic creature that appears briefly about two-thirds into the apocalyptic vision. Some manuscripts{{Which|date=May 2019}} of the original Greek use the symbols χξϛ [[chi (letter)|chi]] [[xi (letter)|xi]] [[Stigma (letter)|stigma]] (or χξϝ with a [[digamma]]), while other manuscripts spell out the number in words.{{cite web|url=http://biblegateway.com/passage/?search=Revelation%2013:18;&version=69;|title=Revelation 13:18|work=Stephanus New Testament|publisher=Bible Gateway|accessdate=2006-06-22}} In modern popular culture, 666 has become one of the most widely recognized symbols for the [[Antichrist]] or, alternatively, the [[Devil in Christianity|devil]]. The number 666 is purportedly used to invoke [[Satan]].{{Citation needed|date=May 2019}} Earnest references to the number occur both among [[apocalypticism|apocalypticist]] [[Christianity|Christian]] groups and in explicitly anti-Christian subcultures. References in contemporary Western art or literature are, more likely than not, intentional references to ''the Beast'' symbolism. Such popular references are therefore too numerous to list. It is common to see the symbolic role of the ''integer'' 666 transferred to the ''digit sequence'' 6-6-6. Some people take the Satanic associations of 666 so seriously that they actively avoid things related to 666 or the digits 6-6-6. This is known as [[hexakosioihexekontahexaphobia]]. The Number of the Beast is cited as [[616 (number)#The Number of the Beast|616]] in some early biblical manuscripts, the earliest known instance being in [[Papyrus 115]].''Novum Testamentum Graece'', Nestle and Aland, 1991, footnote to verse 13:18 of Revelation, page 659: "{{lang|grc|-σιοι δέκα ἕξ}}" as found in ''C'' [''C''=[[Codex Ephraemi Rescriptus]]]; for English see Metzger's ''Textual Commentary on the Greek New Testament'', note on verse 13:18 of Revelation, page 750: "the numeral 616 was also read ..."[http://archive.is/http://web.archive.org/web/20000301070625/www.csad.ox.ac.uk/POxy/beast616.htm The Other Number of the Beast] === Other occurrences === * In the [[Bible]], 666 is the number of [[wiktionary:talent#Noun|talents]] of gold [[Solomon]] collected each year (see {{bibleverse|1|Kings|10:14}} and {{bibleverse|2|Chronicles|9:13}}). * In the Bible, 666 is the number of [[Adonikam]]'s descendants who return to [[Jerusalem]] and [[Judea|Judah]] from the [[Babylonian captivity|Babylonian]] exile (see {{bibleverse||Ezra|2:13}}). * Using gematria, [[Number of the beast#Neron Caesar|Neron Caesar]] transliterated from Greek into Hebrew produces the number 666. The Latin spelling of "Nero Caesar" transliterated into Hebrew produces the number 616. Thus, in the Bible, 666 may have been a coded reference to [[Nero]], the Roman Emperor from 55 to 68 AD.[http://www.numberphile.com/videos/666.html 666 – professors explain Roulette and Nero in detail; numberphile.com] == In other fields == [[Image:666parade.jpeg|thumb|right|222px|666 float in a Paris parade]] * Is the magic sum, or sum of the [[magic constant]]s of a six by six [[magic square]], any row or column of which adds up to 111. * Is the sum of all the numbers on a [[roulette]] wheel (0 through 36). * Was a winning lottery number in the [[1980 Pennsylvania Lottery scandal]], in which equipment was tampered to favor a [[4 (number)|4]] or [[6 (number)|6]] as each of the three individual random digits.{{cite news|url=http://www.newyinzer.com/version1/issue02/n-may.html|title=The Devil Made Him Do It and Left Me There, Comfortable|last=May|first=Steve|work=[[The New Yinzer]]|accessdate=2009-09-13}} * Was the original name of the Macintosh [[SevenDust (computer virus)|SevenDust]] computer virus that was discovered in 1998. * The number is a frequent visual element of [[Aryan Brotherhood]] [[tattoo]]s.{{cite book |last=Brook |first=John Lee |title=Blood In, Blood Out: The Violent Empire of the Aryan Brotherhood |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=ZGe3vuePkxoC |accessdate=10 January 2018 |date=June 2011 |publisher=SCB Distributors |isbn=978-1-900486-80-4 |oclc=793002272}} * [[Aleister Crowley]] adopted the title "the Great Beast 666". As such, 666 is also associated with him, his work, and his religious philosophy of [[Thelema]]. * Molar mass of the high-temperature superconductor [[Yttrium barium copper oxide|YBa2Cu3O7]]. * In China the number is considered to be lucky and is often displayed in shop windows and neon signs.{{cite book |last=Mah|first=Adeline Yen|date=2009|title=China: Land of Dragons and Emperors|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=nEcp5cFeVb0C&lpg=PA7&ots=9evqqCJEYR&dq=666%20luck%20china%20smooth%20flow&pg=PA7#v=onepage&q=666%20luck%20china%20smooth%20flow&f=false|isbn=0375890998|accessdate=2013-12-07}}{{cite web|url=http://au.ibtimes.com/articles/252918/20111121/know-meaning-numbers-chinese-culture.htm#.VFG7feelZeo|title=Know the Meaning of Numbers in Chinese Culture|accessdate=2014-10-30}} In China, 666 can mean "everything goes smoothly" (the number six is similar in pronunciation to the character 流, which means "flowing".{{cite web|url=http://www.newsgd.com/culture/culturenews/200606090016.htm|title=666 – Good day, bad day or just another day?|accessdate=2014-10-30}} ==See also== {{Portal|Mathematics}} * [[Numerology]] == References == {{Reflist}} == External links == {{Commons category|666 (number)}} * {{MathWorld|title=Beast Number|urlname=BeastNumber}} * {{cite web|title=666 – The Number of the Beast|url=http://www.numberphile.com/videos/666.html|work=Numberphile|publisher=[[Brady Haran]]|author=Watts, Peter|author2=Grime, James}} * [http://www.ridingthebeast.com/numbers/nu666.php Symbolism of the number-(''ridingthebeast'')] * [https://web.archive.org/web/20110824044657/http://www.disastercountdown.com/event/666 disastercountdown] * [http://www.novusordoseclorum.com/666.words.html Words that Equal 666] * [http://articles.cnn.com/2007-02-16/us/miami.preacher_1_cult-leader-followers-tattoo?_s=PM:US CNN(U.S.A):Pastor with 666 tattoo] {{Integers|6}} {{DEFAULTSORT:666 (Number)}} [[Category:Integers]] [[Category:Superstitions about numbers]]

pages.title: 700 (number)
pages.text:
{{hatnote|This article is about the numbers 700 through 799; for each individual number, see its section below.}}
{{Infobox number
| number = 700
}}
'''700''' ('''seven hundred''') is the [[natural number]] following [[600 (number)#690s|699]] and preceding [[#700s|701]].

It is the sum of four consecutive [[Prime number|prime]]s (167 + 173 + 179 + 181). It is a [[Harshad number]].
==Integers from 701 to 799==

===700s===
* 701 = prime number, sum of three consecutive primes (229 + 233 + 239), [[Chen prime]], [[Eisenstein prime]] with no imaginary part
* 702 = 2 × 3<sup>3</sup> × 13, [[pronic number]],<ref name=":0">{{Cite web|url=https://oeis.org/A002378|title=Sloane's A002378 : Oblong (or promic, pronic, or heteromecic) numbers|website=The On-Line Encyclopedia of Integer Sequences|publisher=OEIS Foundation|access-date=2016-06-11}}</ref> [[nontotient]], Harshad number
* 703 = 19 × 37, [[triangular number]],<ref name=":1">{{Cite web|url=https://oeis.org/A000217|title=Sloane's A000217 : Triangular numbers|website=The On-Line Encyclopedia of Integer Sequences|publisher=OEIS Foundation|access-date=2016-06-11}}</ref> [[hexagonal number]],<ref name=":2">{{Cite web|url=https://oeis.org/A000384|title=Sloane's A000384 : Hexagonal numbers|website=The On-Line Encyclopedia of Integer Sequences|publisher=OEIS Foundation|access-date=2016-06-11}}</ref> smallest number requiring 73 fifth powers for Waring representation, [[Kaprekar number]],<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://oeis.org/A006886|title=Sloane's A006886 : Kaprekar numbers|website=The On-Line Encyclopedia of Integer Sequences|publisher=OEIS Foundation|access-date=2016-06-11}}</ref> [[703 area code|area code]] for [[Northern Virginia]] along with [[571 area code|571]], a number commonly found in the formula for [[body mass index]]
* 704 = 2<sup>6</sup> × 11, [[Harshad number]], area code for the [[Charlotte, NC]] area.
* 705 = 3 × 5 × 47, [[sphenic number]], smallest [[Lucas pseudoprime]]
* 706 = 2 × 353, nontotient, [[Smith number]]<ref name=":3">{{Cite web|url=https://oeis.org/A006753|title=Sloane's A006753 : Smith numbers|website=The On-Line Encyclopedia of Integer Sequences|publisher=OEIS Foundation|access-date=2016-06-11}}</ref>
* 707 = 7 × 101, sum of five consecutive primes (131 + 137 + 139 + 149 + 151), [[palindromic number]]
* 708 = 2<sup>2</sup> × 3 × 59
* 709 = prime number; [[happy number]].

===710s===
* 710 = 2 × 5 × 71, sphenic number, nontotient
* 711 = 3<sup>2</sup> × 79, Harshad number. Also the phone number of [[Telecommunications Relay Service]], commonly used by the deaf and hard-of-hearing.
* 712 = 2<sup>3</sup> × 89, sum of the first twenty-one primes, totient sum for first 48 integers. It is the largest known number such that it and its 8th power (66,045,000,696,445,844,586,496) have no common digits.
* 713 = 23 × 31, [[Area codes 281, 713, and 832|main area code]] for [[Houston, TX]]. In [[Judaism]] there is 713 letters on a [[Mezuzah]] scroll.
* 714 = 2 × 3 × 7 × 17, sum of twelve consecutive primes (37 + 41 + 43 + 47 + 53 + 59 + 61 + 67 + 71 + 73 + 79 + 83), nontotient, member of [[Ruth–Aaron pair]] (either definition); the smallest number that uses the same digits in bases 2 and 5, area code for [[Orange County, California]].
** 714 is the number of career [[home run]]s hit by [[Babe Ruth]], a record that stood from his last home run on May 25, 1935 until being broken by [[Hank Aaron]] on April 8, 1974.
** ''Flight 714 to Sidney'' is a [[The Adventures of Tintin|Tintin]] graphic novel.
** 714 is the badge number of Sergeant [[Joe Friday]].
* 715 = 5 × 11 × 13, sphenic number, pentagonal number,<ref name=":4">{{Cite web|url=https://oeis.org/A000326|title=Sloane's A000326 : Pentagonal numbers|website=The On-Line Encyclopedia of Integer Sequences|publisher=OEIS Foundation|access-date=2016-06-11}}</ref> [[pentatope number]] ( [[binomial coefficient]] <math>\tbinom {13}4</math>  ),<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://oeis.org/A000332|title=Sloane's A000332 : Binomial coefficient binomial(n,4)|website=The On-Line Encyclopedia of Integer Sequences|publisher=OEIS Foundation|access-date=2016-06-11}}</ref>
Harshad number, member of Ruth-Aaron pair (either definition)
* 716 = 2<sup>2</sup> × 179, area code for [[Buffalo, NY]]
* 717 = 3 × 239, [[palindromic number]]
* 718 = 2 × 359, area code for [[Brooklyn, NY]] and [[Bronx, NY]]
* 719 = prime number, [[factorial prime]] (6! − 1),<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://oeis.org/A088054|title=Sloane's A088054 : Factorial primes|website=The On-Line Encyclopedia of Integer Sequences|publisher=OEIS Foundation|access-date=2016-06-11}}</ref> [[Sophie Germain prime]],<ref name=":5">{{Cite web|url=https://oeis.org/A005384|title=Sloane's A005384 : Sophie Germain primes|website=The On-Line Encyclopedia of Integer Sequences|publisher=OEIS Foundation|access-date=2016-06-11}}</ref> [[safe prime]],<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://oeis.org/A005385|title=Sloane's A005385 : Safe primes|website=The On-Line Encyclopedia of Integer Sequences|publisher=OEIS Foundation|access-date=2016-06-11}}</ref> sum of seven consecutive primes (89 + 97 + 101 + 103 + 107 + 109 + 113), Chen prime, Eisenstein prime with no imaginary part

===720s===

{{Main|720 (number)}}
* 720 (''seven hundred [and] twenty'')= 2<sup>4</sup> × 3<sup>2</sup> × 5.
** [[6 (number)|6]] [[factorial]], [[highly composite number]], [[Harshad number]] in every base from binary to decimal, [[highly totient number]].
** two [[turn (geometry)|round angle]]s (= 2 × [[360 (number)|360]]).
** five [[Gross (unit)|gross]] (= 500 duodecimal, 5 × [[144 (number)|144]]).
** 241-[[polygonal number|gonal number]].
* 721 = 7 × 103, sum of nine consecutive primes (61 + 67 + 71 + 73 + 79 + 83 + 89 + 97 + 101), [[centered hexagonal number]],<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://oeis.org/A003215|title=Sloane's A003215 : Hex (or centered hexagonal) numbers|website=The On-Line Encyclopedia of Integer Sequences|publisher=OEIS Foundation|access-date=2016-06-11}}</ref> smallest number that is the difference of two positive cubes in two ways, 
* 722 = 2 × 19<sup>2</sup>, nontotient
** [[G.722]] is a freely available file format for audio file compression. The files are often named with the extension "722".
* 723 = 3 × 241
* 724 = 2<sup>2</sup> × 181, sum of four consecutive primes (173 + 179 + 181 + 191), sum of six consecutive primes (107 + 109 + 113 + 127 + 131 + 137), nontotient
** the number of [[Eight queens puzzle|''n''-queens problem]] solutions for ''n'' = 10,
* 725 = 5<sup>2</sup> × 29
* 726 = 2 × 3 × 11<sup>2</sup>, [[pentagonal pyramidal number]]<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://oeis.org/A002411|title=Sloane's A002411 : Pentagonal pyramidal numbers|website=The On-Line Encyclopedia of Integer Sequences|publisher=OEIS Foundation|access-date=2016-06-11}}</ref>
* 727 = prime number, [[palindromic prime]], [[lucky prime]]<ref name=":6">{{Cite web|url=https://oeis.org/A031157|title=Sloane's A031157 : Numbers that are both lucky and prime|website=The On-Line Encyclopedia of Integer Sequences|publisher=OEIS Foundation|access-date=2016-06-11}}</ref>
* 728 = 2<sup>3</sup> × 7 × 13, nontotient, [[Smith number]],<ref name=":3" /> [[cabtaxi number]]<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://oeis.org/A047696|title=Sloane's A047696 : Smallest positive number that can be written in n ways as a sum of two (not necessarily positive) cubes|website=The On-Line Encyclopedia of Integer Sequences|publisher=OEIS Foundation|access-date=2016-06-11}}</ref>
* 729 = 3<sup>6</sup> = 27<sup>2</sup>.
** the [[square number|square]] of [[27 (number)|27]], and the [[cube (arithmetics)|cube]] of [[9 (number)|9]], and as a consequence of these properties, a [[perfect totient number]].<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://oeis.org/A082897|title=Sloane's A082897 : Perfect totient numbers|website=The On-Line Encyclopedia of Integer Sequences|publisher=OEIS Foundation|access-date=2016-06-11}}</ref>
** [[centered octagonal number]],<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://oeis.org/A016754|title=Sloane's A016754 : Odd squares: a(n) = (2n+1)^2. Also centered octagonal numbers|website=The On-Line Encyclopedia of Integer Sequences|publisher=OEIS Foundation|access-date=2016-06-11}}</ref> Smith number<ref name=":3" />
** the number of times a philosopher's pleasure is greater than a tyrant's pleasure according to Plato in [[The Republic (Plato)|the Republic]]
** the largest three digit cube. (9 x 9 x 9)
** the largest three digit sixth power. (3 x 3 x 3 x 3 x 3 x 3)

===730s===
* 730 = 2 × 5 × 73, sphenic number, nontotient, Harshad number, [[happy number]]
* 731 = 17 × 43, sum of three consecutive primes (239 + 241 + 251)
* 732 = 2<sup>2</sup> × 3 × 61, sum of eight consecutive primes (73 + 79 + 83 + 89 + 97 + 101 + 103 + 107), sum of ten consecutive primes (53 + 59 + 61 + 67 + 71 + 73 + 79 + 83 + 89 + 97), Harshad number
* 733 = prime number, [[balanced prime]],<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://oeis.org/A006562|title=Sloane's A006562 : Balanced primes|website=The On-Line Encyclopedia of Integer Sequences|publisher=OEIS Foundation|access-date=2016-06-11}}</ref> [[permutable prime]], sum of five consecutive primes (137 + 139 + 149 + 151 + 157)
* 734 = 2 × 367, nontotient
* 735 = 3 × 5 × 7<sup>2</sup>, [[Harshad number]], Zuckerman number, smallest number such that uses same digits as its distinct prime factors
* 736 = 2<sup>5</sup> × 23, [[centered heptagonal number]],<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://oeis.org/A069099|title=Sloane's A069099 : Centered heptagonal numbers|website=The On-Line Encyclopedia of Integer Sequences|publisher=OEIS Foundation|access-date=2016-06-11}}</ref> nice [[Friedman number]] since 736 = 7 + 3<sup>6</sup>, [[Harshad number]]
* 737 = 11 × 67, [[palindromic number]], model number of the [[Boeing 737]] jet airliner.
* 738 = 2 × 3<sup>2</sup> × 41, Harshad number, designation for a [[Boeing 737-800]] jet airliner.
* 739 = prime number, [[strictly non-palindromic number]],<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://oeis.org/A016038|title=Sloane's A016038 : Strictly non-palindromic numbers|website=The On-Line Encyclopedia of Integer Sequences|publisher=OEIS Foundation|access-date=2016-06-11}}</ref> lucky prime,<ref name=":6" /> [[happy number]]

===740s===
* 740 = 2<sup>2</sup> × 5 × 37, nontotient
* 741 = 3 × 13 × 19, sphenic number, triangular number<ref name=":1" />
* 742 = 2 × 7 × 53, sphenic number, [[decagonal number]].<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://oeis.org/A001107|title=Sloane's A001107 : 10-gonal (or decagonal) numbers|website=The On-Line Encyclopedia of Integer Sequences|publisher=OEIS Foundation|access-date=2016-06-11}}</ref> It is the smallest number that is one more than triple its reverse.

{{Main|743 (number)}}
* 743 = prime number, Sophie Germain prime, Chen prime, Eisenstein prime with no imaginary part
* 744 = 2<sup>3</sup> × 3 × 31, sum of four consecutive primes (179 + 181 + 191 + 193). It is the coefficient of the first degree term of the expansion of Klein's [[j-invariant]]. Furthermore, 744 =3 × 248 where 248 is the dimension of the Lie algebra [[E8 (mathematics)|''E''<sub>8</sub>]].
* 745 = 5 × 149
* 746 = 2 × 373, nontotient
** 746 = 1<sup>7</sup> + 2<sup>4</sup> + 3<sup>6</sup>
* 747 = 3<sup>2</sup> × 83, [[palindromic number]], model number of the [[Boeing 747]] jet airliner, perhaps the most famous Boeing aircraft
* 748 = 2<sup>2</sup> × 11 × 17, nontotient, [[happy number]], primitive abundant number<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://oeis.org/A091191|title=Sloane's A091191 : Primitive abundant numbers|website=The On-Line Encyclopedia of Integer Sequences|publisher=OEIS Foundation|access-date=2016-06-11}}</ref>
* 749 = 7 × 107, sum of three consecutive primes (241 + 251 + 257)

===750s===
* 750 = 2 × 3 × 5<sup>3</sup>, [[nonagonal number|enneagonal number]].<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://oeis.org/A001106|title=Sloane's A001106 : 9-gonal (or enneagonal or nonagonal) numbers|website=The On-Line Encyclopedia of Integer Sequences|publisher=OEIS Foundation|access-date=2016-06-11}}</ref>
* 751 = prime number, Chen prime
* 752 = 2<sup>4</sup> × 47, nontotient
* 753 = 3 × 251
* 754 = 2 × 13 × 29, sphenic number, nontotient, totient sum for first 49 integers
* 755 = 5 × 151. In 1976, Major League Baseball player [[Hank Aaron]] ended his career with a Major League record 755 home runs (record now held by [[Barry Bonds]]).
* 756 = 2<sup>2</sup> × 3<sup>3</sup> × 7, sum of six consecutive primes (109 + 113 + 127 + 131 + 137 + 139), pronic number,<ref name=":0" /> Harshad number
* 757 = prime number, palindromic prime, sum of seven consecutive primes (97 + 101 + 103 + 107 + 109 + 113 + 127), [[happy number]]
** "The 757" is a local nickname for the [[Hampton Roads]] area in the U.S. state of [[Virginia]], derived from [[Area code 757|the telephone area code]] that covers almost all of the metropolitan area.
* 758 = 2 × 379, nontotient
* 759 = 3 × 11 × 23, sphenic number, sum of five consecutive primes (139 + 149 + 151 + 157 + 163)

===760s===
* 760 = 2<sup>3</sup> × 5 × 19, [[centered triangular number]]<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://oeis.org/A005448|title=Sloane's A005448 : Centered triangular numbers|website=The On-Line Encyclopedia of Integer Sequences|publisher=OEIS Foundation|access-date=2016-06-11}}</ref>
* 761 = prime number, Sophie Germain prime,<ref name=":5" /> Chen prime, Eisenstein prime with no imaginary part, [[centered square number]]<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://oeis.org/A001844|title=Sloane's A001844 : Centered square numbers|website=The On-Line Encyclopedia of Integer Sequences|publisher=OEIS Foundation|access-date=2016-06-11}}</ref>
* 762 = 2 × 3 × 127, sphenic number, sum of four consecutive primes (181 + 191 + 193 + 197), nontotient, Smith number,<ref name=":3" /> see also [[Six nines in pi]]
* 763 = 7 × 109, sum of nine consecutive primes (67 + 71 + 73 + 79 + 83 + 89 + 97 + 101 + 103)
* 764 = 2<sup>2</sup> × 191, [[Telephone number (mathematics)|telephone number]]<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://oeis.org/A000085|title=Sloane's A000085 : Number of self-inverse permutations on n letters, also known as involutions|website=The On-Line Encyclopedia of Integer Sequences|publisher=OEIS Foundation|access-date=2016-06-11}}</ref>
* 765 = 3<sup>2</sup> × 5 × 17
** a [[Japanese language|Japanese]] word-play for [[Namco]]; 
* 766 = 2 × 383, [[centered pentagonal number]],<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://oeis.org/A005891|title=Sloane's A005891 : Centered pentagonal numbers|website=The On-Line Encyclopedia of Integer Sequences|publisher=OEIS Foundation|access-date=2016-06-11}}</ref> nontotient, sum of twelve consecutive primes (41 + 43 + 47 + 53 + 59 + 61 + 67 + 71 + 73 + 79 + 83 + 89), [[happy number]]
* 767 = 13 × 59, [[Thabit number]] (2<sup>8</sup> × 3  − 1), [[palindromic number]]
* 768 = 2<sup>8</sup> × 3, sum of eight consecutive primes (79 + 83 + 89 + 97 + 101 + 103 + 107 + 109)
* 769 = prime number, Chen prime, lucky prime,<ref name=":6" /> [[Proth prime]]<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://oeis.org/A080076|title=Sloane's A080076 : Proth primes|website=The On-Line Encyclopedia of Integer Sequences|publisher=OEIS Foundation|access-date=2016-06-11}}</ref>

===770s===
* 770 = 2 × 5 × 7 × 11, nontotient, Harshad number
**  Famous room party in New Orleans hotel room 770, giving the name to a well known [[science fiction fanzine]] called [[File 770]]
** [[770 Eastern Parkway#Symbolism of "770"|Holds special importance]] in the [[Chabad]]-Lubavitch [[Hasidic Judaism|Hasidic movement]].
* 771 = 3 × 257, sum of three consecutive primes in [[arithmetic progression]] (251 + 257 + 263). Since 771 is the product of the distinct [[Fermat prime]]s 3 and 257, a [[regular polygon]] with 771 sides can be constructed using [[compass and straightedge]], and <math>\cos\left(\frac{2\pi}{771}\right)</math> can be written in terms of square roots.
* 772 = 2<sup>2</sup> × 193
* 773 = prime number, Eisenstein prime with no imaginary part, [[tetranacci number]]<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://oeis.org/A000078|title=Sloane's A000078 : Tetranacci numbers|website=The On-Line Encyclopedia of Integer Sequences|publisher=OEIS Foundation|access-date=2016-06-11}}</ref>
* 774 = 2 × 3<sup>2</sup> × 43, nontotient, totient sum for first 50 integers, Harshad number
* 775 = 5<sup>2</sup> × 31, member of the [[Mian–Chowla sequence]],<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://oeis.org/A005282|title=Sloane's A005282 : Mian-Chowla sequence|website=The On-Line Encyclopedia of Integer Sequences|publisher=OEIS Foundation|access-date=2016-06-11}}</ref> [[happy number]]
* 776 = 2<sup>3</sup> × 97

{{Main|777 (number)}}
* 777 = 3 × 7 × 37, sphenic number, Harshad number, [[palindromic number]], model number of the [[Boeing 777]] jet airliner, 3333 in [[senary]] (base 6) counting.
** The numbers 3 and 7 are considered both "perfect numbers" under Hebrew tradition.<ref>{{cite web | last=Posner | first=Eliezer | title=On the Meaning of Three | url=http://www.chabad.org/library/article_cdo/aid/608781/jewish/On-the-Meaning-of-Three.htm | publisher=Chabad | accessdate=2 July 2016}}</ref><ref>{{cite web | last=Dennis | first=Geoffrey | title=Judaism & Numbers | url=http://www.myjewishlearning.com/beliefs/Issues/Magic_and_the_Supernatural/Practices_and_Beliefs/Incantations/Names_and_Numbers/Numbers.shtml | publisher=My Jewish Learning | accessdate=2 July 2016}}</ref> 777 is also found in the title of the book ''[[777 and other Qabalistic writings of Aleister Crowley]]''.
* 778 = 2 × 389, nontotient, Smith number<ref name=":3" />
* 779 = 19 × 41, [[highly cototient number]]<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://oeis.org/A100827|title=Sloane's A100827 : Highly cototient numbers|website=The On-Line Encyclopedia of Integer Sequences|publisher=OEIS Foundation|access-date=2016-06-11}}</ref>

===780s===
* 780 = 2<sup>2</sup> × 3 × 5 × 13, sum of four consecutive [[prime number|primes]] in a [[Prime quadruplet|quadruplet]] (191, 193, 197, and 199); sum of ten consecutive primes (59 + 61 + 67 + 71 + 73 + 79 + 83 + 89 + 97 + 101), [[triangular number]],<ref name=":1" /> [[hexagonal number]],<ref name=":2" /> [[Harshad number]]
** 780 and 990 are the fourth smallest pair of triangular numbers whose sum and difference (1770 and 210) are also triangular.
* 781 = 11 × 71, sum of powers of 5/repdigit in base 5 (11111), [[Mertens function]](781) = 0
* 782 = 2 × 17 × 23, sphenic number, nontotient, pentagonal number,<ref name=":4" /> Harshad number, also, 782 gear used by U.S. Marines
* 783 = 3<sup>3</sup> × 29
* 784 = 2<sup>4</sup> × 7<sup>2</sup> = 28<sup>2</sup> = <math>1^3+2^3+3^3+4^3+5^3+6^3+7^3</math>, the sum of the cubes of the first seven integers, [[happy number]]
* 785 = 5 × 157, Mertens function(785) = 0

{{Main|786 (number)}}
* 786  = 2 × 3 × 131, sphenic number. See also [[Basmala#Numerology|its use in Muslim numerological symbolism]].
* 787 = prime number, sum of five consecutive primes (149 + 151 + 157 + 163 + 167), Chen prime, [[lucky prime]],<ref name=":6" /> palindromic prime.
* 788 = 2<sup>2</sup> × 197, nontotient
* 789 = 3 × 263, sum of three consecutive primes (257 + 263 + 269)

===790s===

{{Main|790 (number)}}
* 790 = 2 × 5 × 79, sphenic number, nontotient
* 791 = 7 × 113, sum of the first twenty-two primes, sum of seven consecutive primes (101 + 103 + 107 + 109 + 113 + 127 + 131)
* 792 = 2<sup>3</sup> × 3<sup>2</sup> × 11, number of [[partition (number theory)|partitions]] of 21,<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://oeis.org/A000041|title=Sloane's A000041 : a(n) = number of partitions of n|website=The On-Line Encyclopedia of Integer Sequences|publisher=OEIS Foundation|access-date=2016-06-11}}</ref> [[binomial coefficient]] <math>\tbinom {12}5</math>, Harshad number
* 793 = 13 × 61, Mertens function(793) = 0, [[star number]],<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://oeis.org/A003154|title=Sloane's A003154 : Centered 12-gonal numbers. Also star numbers|website=The On-Line Encyclopedia of Integer Sequences|publisher=OEIS Foundation|access-date=2016-06-11}}</ref> [[happy number]]
* 794 = 2 × 397, nontotient
* 795 = 3 × 5 × 53, Mertens function(795) = 0
* 796 = 2<sup>2</sup> × 199, sum of six consecutive primes (113 + 127 + 131 + 137 + 139 + 149), Mertens function(796) = 0
* 797 = prime number, Chen prime, Eisenstein prime with no imaginary part, palindromic prime
* 798 = 2 × 3 × 7 × 19, Mertens function(798) = 0, nontotient
* 799 = 17 × 47

[[Category:Integers]]

pages.title: 720 (number)
pages.text:
{{Infobox number
| number = 720
| divisor = [[1 (number)|1]], [[2 (number)|2]], [[3 (number)|3]], [[4 (number)|4]], [[5 (number)|5]], [[6 (number)|6]], [[8 (number)|8]], [[9 (number)|9]], [[10 (number)|10]], [[12 (number)|12]], [[15 (number)|15]], [[16 (number)|16]], [[18 (number)|18]], [[20 (number)|20]], [[24 (number)|24]], [[30 (number)|30]], [[36 (number)|36]], [[40 (number)|40]], [[45 (number)|45]], [[48 (number)|48]], [[60 (number)|60]], [[72 (number)|72]], [[80 (number)|80]], [[90 (number)|90]], [[120 (number)|120]], [[144 (number)|144]], [[180 (number)|180]], [[240 (number)|240]], [[360 (number)|360]], 720
}}
'''720''' ('''seven hundred [and] twenty''') is the [[natural number]] following [[700 (number)#710s|719]] and preceding [[700 (number)#720s|721]].

It is 6! ([[6 (number)|6]] [[factorial]]), a [[composite number]] with thirty [[divisor]]s, more than any number below, making it a [[highly composite number]]. It is a [[Harshad number]] in every base from binary to decimal.

720 is expressible as the product of consecutive integers in two different ways: {{math|1=720 = 1 × 2 × 3 × 4 × 5 × 6}} <!-- there's a trivial third way: "1" factor can be dropped -->, and {{math|1=720 = 8 × 9 × 10 }}.
<ref>
{{cite book|last=Wells|first=David
  | authorlink = David Wells
  | coauthors =|title=[[The Penguin Dictionary of Curious and Interesting Numbers]]|publisher=Penguin Books|year=1987|location=London|pages=719|url=|doi=|id=|isbn=}}</ref>

There are 49 solutions to the equation [[Euler's totient function|φ]](''x'') = 720, more than any integer below it, making 720 a [[highly totient number]].

720 is a 241-[[polygonal number|gonal number]].

==In other fields==

720 is:
* A common vertical [[display resolution]] for [[High-definition television|HDTV]] (see [[720p]]).
* 720° is two full rotations; the term "720" refers to a [[skateboarding trick]].
* [[720°]] is also the name of a skateboarding video game.
* 720 is a dual [[area codes 303 and 720|area code]] in the [[Denver]] Metro Area along with 303.
* 720° is the sum of all the [[defect (geometry)|defect]]s of any [[polyhedron]].
* 720 is a short form of saying [[Boeing 720]], an airliner which is no longer in service.

For the year AD, see [[720]].

==References==

pages.title: 743 (number)
777 (number)
pages.text:
{{Infobox number
| number = 777
}}
'''777''' ('''seven hundred [and] seventy-seven''') is the [[natural number]] following [[700 (number)#770s|776]] and preceding [[700 (number)#770s|778]]. The number 777 is significant in numerous religious and political contexts.

==Religious significance==
According to the [[Bible]], [[Lamech (father of Noah)|Lamech, the father of Noah]] lived for 777 years.<ref>[http://biblehub.com/niv/genesis/5.htm "From Adam to Noah"], Biblica Inc.,1973.Retrieved on 27 March 2014</ref> Other connections to 777 are noted in the sections below.

===Judaism===
The numbers 3<ref>{{cite web |last=Posner |first=Eliezer |title= On the Meaning of Three |url=http://www.chabad.org/library/article_cdo/aid/608781/jewish/On-the-Meaning-of-Three.htm |publisher= Chabad |accessdate= 6 December 2013}}</ref> and 7<ref>{{cite web |last=Dennis |first= Geoffrey |title= Judaism & Numbers |url=http://www.myjewishlearning.com/beliefs/Issues/Magic_and_the_Supernatural/Practices_and_Beliefs/Incantations/Names_and_Numbers/Numbers.shtml |publisher=My Jewish Learning |accessdate= 6 December 2013}}</ref> both are considered "perfect numbers" under Hebrew tradition.

===Christianity===
[[List of Christian denominations|Christian denominations]] consider seven to be a holy number because [[Book of Genesis|Genesis]] says that God rested on the 7th day and man was created on the 6th day.<ref>Loughran, David. [http://stewartonbibleschool.org/prophecy/no777.html "The Number 777"], Stewarton Bible School, 1995. Retrieved on 25 March 2014.</ref> Because God rested on the 7th day, that is the reason for the observance of the Hebrew [[Sabbath]] on the last day of the week. The 7th day of the week is indicated on the Hebrew [[Lunar calendar]] containing 13 months of four weeks each. According to the American publication, the [[Orthodox Study Bible]], 777 represents the threefold perfection of the [[Trinity]].<ref>{{cite web |title= Properties of the number 777 |url= http://www.ridingthebeast.com/numbers/nu777.php |publisher= Riding the Beast |accessdate=6 December 2013}}</ref> The number 777, as triple 7, can be contrasted against triple 6, for the [[Number of the Beast]] as 666 (rather than variant 616).

===Thelema===
777 is also found in the title of the book ''[[777 and Other Qabalistic Writings of Aleister Crowley]]'' pertaining to the law of [[thelema]].<ref>Crowley, Aleister. ["777 And Other Qabalistic Writings of Aleister Crowley"]. Weiser Books, June 1, 1986. Retrieved on March 27, 2014.</ref>

=== Other traditions ===
In other traditions and teachings, seven is seen as the perfect number that holds creation and the universe together.<ref>{{Cite book |url= http://777.community |title= 777: Messages from the Elder Gods (777 Series Book 1) |last=Nunitus|first=Septem |publisher= Elder Gods Press |year=2016 |asin= B01I0EUQGA |location= |pages=5}}</ref> Religious or mythological cosmology refers to [[Seven Heavens|seven heavens]], ancient Indian spiritual texts detail [[Chakra|seven chakras]] and esoteric teachings describe seven [[Plane (esotericism)|planes]] of creation.

==Political significance==

===Afrikaner Weerstandsbeweging===
The [[Afrikaner Resistance Movement]] (''Afrikaner Weerstandsbeweging'', AWB), a Boer-nationalist movement in [[South Africa]], used the number 777 as part of their emblem.<ref>[http://articles.latimes.com/keyword/afrikaner-resistance-movement "Afrikaner Resistance Movement"], LA times, 3 April 2010. Retrieved March 24, 2014.</ref>

The number refers to a triumph of "God's number" 7 over the [[number of the beast|Devil's number 666]].<ref>[http://www.volkstaat.net/index.php?option=com_content&view=article&id=1269:the-/three-sevens-flag&catid=57:awbeng&Itemid=101 "The Three Sevens flag"], 8 March 2014. Retrieved on 14 March 2014.</ref> On the AWB flag, the numbers are arranged in a [[triskelion]] shape, resembling the Nazi [[hakenkreuz]].

==Computing==
In Unix's [[chmod]], change-access-mode command, the value 777 grants all file-access permissions to all user types in a file storage system.

==Commercial==

=== Airplanes ===
{{main article|Boeing 777}}
[[File:United Airlines B777-200 N780UA.jpg|thumbnail|right|Boeing 777-200]]
[[Boeing]], the largest manufacturer of airliners in the United States, released the [[Boeing 777]] (commonly nicknamed the ''Triple Seven'') in June 1995.<ref>{{cite web|title=Boeing 777 Facts|url=http://www.boeing.com/boeing/commercial/777family/pf/pf_facts.page|accessdate=5 December 2013}}</ref> The family of 777's include the [[Boing 777#777-200|777-200]], [[Boeing 777#777-200ER|777-200ER]], the [[Boeing 777#777-300|777-300]], the [[Boeing 777#777-200LR|777-200LR Worldliner]], the [[Boeing 777#777-300ER|777-300ER]], and the [[Boeing 777#777 Freighter|777 Freighter]].<ref>{{cite web|title=Technical Information|url=http://www.boeing.com/boeing/commercial/777family/specs.page?|publisher=Boeing|accessdate=5 December 2013}}</ref>

===777 Tower===

[[777 Tower]] is a office building situated in the US and it was built in 1991. <ref>http://articles.latimes.com/1990-04-08/news/vw-1598_1_stretched-skin-style</ref>

==Gambling and luck==
777 is used on most [[slot machines]] in the United States to identify a jackpot. As it is considered a lucky number, banknotes with a serial number containing 777 tend to be valued by collectors and numismatists. The [[US Mint]] and the [[Bureau of Engraving and Printing]] sells uncirculated 777 $1 bills for this reason.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.coinnews.net/2012/08/28/1-lucky-777-notes-introduced-by-bureau-of-engraving-and-printing/|title=$1 Lucky 777 Notes Introduced by Bureau of Engraving and Printing|last=Kay|first=Rhonda|date=2012-08-28|website=Coin News|language=en-US|access-date=2019-02-07}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=https://catalog.usmint.gov/1-lucky-777-note-B1501.html|title=$1 Lucky 777 Note|website=United States Mint|language=en|access-date=2019-02-07}}</ref>

pages.title: 786 (number)
pages.text:
{{for|the year|786}}
{{Infobox number
| number = 786
}}
'''786''' ('''seven hundred [and] eighty-six''') is the [[natural number]] following [[785 (number)|785]] and preceding [[787 (number)|787]].

==In mathematics==
'''786''' is:
*a [[sphenic number]].
*a Harshad number in bases 4, 5, 7, 14 and 16.
*the aliquot sum of 510.
*part of the 321329-aliquot tree. The complete aliquot sequence starting at 498 is: 498, 510, '''786''', 798, 1122, 1470, 2634, 2646, 4194, 4932, 7626, 8502, 9978, 9990, 17370, 28026, 35136, 67226, 33616, 37808, 40312, 35288, 37072, 45264, 79728, 146448, 281166, 281178, 363942, 424638, 526338, 722961, 321329, 1, 0

50 can be [[integer partition|partitioned]] into powers of two in 786 different ways {{OEIS|id=A000123}}.

786 might be the largest ''n'' for which the value of the [[central binomial coefficient]] <math>{}_{2n}\!C_n</math> is not divisible by an odd prime squared. If there is a larger such number, it would have to be at least 157450 (see {{OEIS2C|id=A059097}}).

==Area code==
786 is a [[United States]] [[area code]] in [[Miami-Dade County]]. As an ''overlay'' area code, it shares geography with other codes in order to increase the area's pool of usable numbers, bringing ten-digit dialing to the Florida Keys.

==In other fields==
* [[80786]] - 7th generation x86 like [[Athlon]] and [[Intel Pentium 4]]
* The [[Unstructured Supplementary Service Data|USSD]] code 786, typically dialed as ##786# or *#786#, opens the RTN dialog on some cell phones. "RTN" is 786 when dialed on an [[E.161]] telephone pad.
* In the [[New General Catalogue]], NGC786 is a magnitude 13.5 [[spiral galaxy]] in the constellation [[Aries (constellation)|Aries]]. Additionally, [[786 Bredichina]] is an [[asteroid]].
* In [[juggling]], 786 as fourhanded [[Siteswap]] is also known as [http://passingwiki.org/wiki/French_3-count French Threecount].
*In [[Islam]], 786 is often used to represent the Arabic phrase ''[[Basmala|Bismilla]]''.

==In films==
* Vijay Verma's ([[Amitabh Bachchan]]) [[coolie]] number in the 1975 Hindi film [[Deewaar]].
* [[Rajnikanth]]'s coolie number in the 1981 Tamil film [[Thee (1981 film)|Thee]], which again was a remake of the Hindi film [[Deewaar]].
* Iqbal Khan ([[Amitabh Bachchan]]) in the 1983 Hindi film [[Coolie (1983 Hindi film)|Coolie]] had this number for his coolie number called '''Billa no. 786''' (badge number 786). 
* [[Amitabh Bachchan]] has indicated that he thinks this is an auspicious number as the 1975 Hindi film [[Deewaar]] was his first big hit, and he was seriously injured but survived while wearing this number during the shooting of the 1983 Hindi film [[Coolie (1983 Hindi film)|Coolie]].
* The Telugu actor [[Chiranjeevi]] sported this number in the 1988 Telugu film [[Khaidi No.786]].
* Veer Pratap Singh's ([[Shahrukh Khan]]) prisoner number in the 2004 Hindi film [[Veer-Zaara]].
* The registration number of Sultan's ([[Ajay Devgan]]) car in the 2010 Hindi film [[Once Upon a Time in Mumbaai]] is MRH 786.
* In the 2011 Tamil film [[Mankatha]], in the scene where Vinayak Mahadev ([[Ajith Kumar]]) shoots Prem ([[Premgi Amaren]]), Vinayak checks whether Prem is dead or not. The coat that Prem wears has a gold plate at his chest. Vinayak takes out the gold plate and the number is 786.
* [[Ashish R Mohan]]'s 2012 Hindi film [[Khiladi 786]] features [[Akshay Kumar]] in the title role. The same film was released in [[Pakistan]] without the number 786.<ref>http://timesofindia.indiatimes.com/entertainment/movie-reviews/hindi/Khiladi-786/movie-review/17504813.cms</ref>

800 (number)
pages.text:
{{about|the number|the year|800|other uses|800 (disambiguation)}}
{{Infobox number
| number = 800
}}
'''800''' ('''eight hundred''') is the [[natural number]] following 799 and preceding 801.

It is the sum of four consecutive primes (193 + 197 + 199 + 211). It is a [[Harshad number]].

==Integers from 801 to 899==

===800s===
{{Main|801 (number)}}
* 801 = 3<sup>2</sup> × 89, Harshad number
* 802 = 2 × 401, sum of eight consecutive primes (83 + 89 + 97 + 101 + 103 + 107 + 109 + 113), [[nontotient]], [[happy number]]
* 803 = 11 × 73, sum of three consecutive primes (263 + 269 + 271), sum of nine consecutive primes (71 + 73 + 79 + 83 + 89 + 97 + 101 + 103 + 107), Harshad number
* 804 = 2<sup>2</sup> × 3 × 67, nontotient, Harshad number
** "The 804" is a local nickname for the [[Greater Richmond Region]] of the U.S. state of [[Virginia]], derived from [[Area code 804|its telephone area code]] (although the area code covers a larger area).
* 805 = 5 × 7 × 23
* 806 = 2 × 13 × 31, [[sphenic number]], nontotient, totient sum for first 51 integers, [[happy number]]
* 807 = 3 × 269
* 808 = 2<sup>3</sup> × 101, [[strobogrammatic number]]<ref name=":0">{{Cite OEIS|1=A000787|2=Strobogrammatic numbers|accessdate=2016-06-11}}</ref>
* 809 = prime number, [[Sophie Germain prime]],<ref>{{Cite OEIS|1=A005384|2=Sophie Germain primes|accessdate=2016-06-11}}</ref> [[Chen prime]], [[Eisenstein prime]] with no imaginary part

===810s===
* 810 = 2 × 3<sup>4</sup> × 5, Harshad number
* 811 = prime number, sum of five consecutive primes (151 + 157 + 163 + 167 + 173), Chen prime, [[happy number]], the [[Mertens function]] of 811 returns 0
* 812 = 2<sup>2</sup> × 7 × 29, [[pronic number]],<ref name=":1">{{Cite OEIS|1=A002378|2=Oblong (or promic, pronic, or heteromecic) numbers|accessdate=2016-06-11}}</ref> the Mertens function of 812 returns 0
* 813 = 3 × 271
* 814 = 2 × 11 × 37, sphenic number, the Mertens function of 814 returns 0, nontotient
* 815 = 5 × 163
* 816 = 2<sup>4</sup> × 3 × 17, [[tetrahedral number]],<ref>{{Cite OEIS|1=A000292|2=Tetrahedral numbers|accessdate=2016-06-11}}</ref> [[Padovan sequence|Padovan number]],<ref>{{Cite OEIS|1=A000931|2=Padovan sequence|accessdate=2016-06-11}}</ref> Zuckerman number
* 817 = 19 × 43, sum of three consecutive primes (269 + 271 + 277), [[centered hexagonal number]]<ref>{{Cite OEIS|1=A003215|2=Hex (or centered hexagonal) numbers|accessdate=2016-06-11}}</ref>
* 818 = 2 × 409, nontotient, [[strobogrammatic number]]<ref name=":0" />
* 819 = 3<sup>2</sup> × 7 × 13, [[square pyramidal number]]<ref>{{Cite OEIS|1=A000330|2=Square pyramidal numbers|accessdate=2016-06-11}}</ref>

===820s===
* 820 = 2<sup>2</sup> × 5 × 41, [[triangular number]],<ref name=":2">{{Cite OEIS|1=A000217|2=Triangular numbers|accessdate=2016-06-11}}</ref> Harshad number, [[happy number]], repdigit (1111) in base 9
* 821 = prime number, [[twin prime]], Eisenstein prime with no imaginary part, [[prime quadruplet]] with 823, 827, 829
* 822 = 2 × 3 × 137, sum of twelve consecutive primes (43 + 47 + 53 + 59 + 61 + 67 + 71 + 73 + 79 + 83 + 89 + 97), sphenic number, member of the [[Mian–Chowla sequence]]<ref>{{Cite OEIS|1=A005282|2=Mian-Chowla sequence|accessdate=2016-06-11}}</ref>
* 823 = prime number, [[twin prime]], the Mertens function of 823 returns 0, prime quadruplet with 821, 827, 829
* 824 = 2<sup>3</sup> × 103, sum of ten consecutive primes (61 + 67 + 71 + 73 + 79 + 83 + 89 + 97 + 101 + 103), the Mertens function of 824 returns 0, nontotient
* 825 = 3 × 5<sup>2</sup> × 11, [[Smith number]],<ref name=":3">{{Cite OEIS|1=A006753|2=Smith numbers|accessdate=2016-06-11}}</ref> the Mertens function of 825 returns 0, Harshad number
* 826 = 2 × 7 × 59, sphenic number
* 827 = prime number, [[twin prime]], part of prime quadruplet with {821, 823, 829}, sum of seven consecutive primes (103 + 107 + 109 + 113 + 127 + 131 + 137), Chen prime, Eisenstein prime with no imaginary part, [[strictly non-palindromic number]]<ref name=":4">{{Cite OEIS|1=A016038|2=Strictly non-palindromic numbers|accessdate=2016-06-11}}</ref>
* 828 = 2<sup>2</sup> × 3<sup>2</sup> × 23, Harshad number
* 829 = prime number, [[twin prime]], part of prime quadruplet with {827, 823, 821}, sum of three consecutive primes (271 + 277 + 281), Chen prime

===830s===
* 830 = 2 × 5 × 83, sphenic number, sum of four consecutive primes (197 + 199 + 211 + 223), nontotient, totient sum for first 52 integers
* 831 = 3 × 277
* 832 = 2<sup>6</sup> × 13, Harshad number
* 833 = 7<sup>2</sup> × 17
* 834 = 2 × 3 × 139, sphenic number, sum of six consecutive primes (127 + 131 + 137 + 139 + 149 + 151), nontotient
* 835 = 5 × 167, [[Motzkin number]]<ref>{{Cite OEIS|1=A001006|2=Motzkin numbers|accessdate=2016-06-11}}</ref>

{{Main|836 (number)}}
* 836 = 2<sup>2</sup> × 11 × 19, [[weird number]]
* 837 = 3<sup>3</sup> × 31
* 838 = 2 × 419
* 839 = prime number, [[safe prime]],<ref name=":5">{{Cite OEIS|1=A005385|2=Safe primes|accessdate=2016-06-11}}</ref> sum of five consecutive primes (157 + 163 + 167 + 173 + 179), Chen prime, Eisenstein prime with no imaginary part, [[highly cototient number]]<ref>{{Cite OEIS|1=A100827|2=Highly cototient numbers|accessdate=2016-06-11}}</ref>

===840s===
* 840 = 2<sup>3</sup> × 3 × 5 × 7, [[highly composite number]],<ref>{{Cite OEIS|1=A002182|2=Highly composite numbers|accessdate=2016-06-11}}</ref> smallest numbers divisible by the numbers 1 to 8 (lowest common multiple of 1 to 8), sparsely totient number,<ref name=":6">{{Cite OEIS|1=A036913|2=Sparsely totient numbers|accessdate=2016-06-11}}</ref> Harshad number in base 2 through base 10
* 841 = 29<sup>2</sup> = 20<sup>2</sup> + 21<sup>2</sup>, sum of three consecutive primes (277 + 281 + 283), sum of nine consecutive primes (73 + 79 + 83 + 89 + 97 + 101 + 103 + 107 + 109), [[centered square number]],<ref>{{Cite OEIS|1=A001844|2=Centered square numbers|accessdate=2016-06-11}}</ref> [[centered heptagonal number]],<ref>{{Cite OEIS|1=A069099|2=Centered heptagonal numbers|accessdate=2016-06-11}}</ref> [[centered octagonal number]]<ref>{{Cite OEIS|1=A016754|2=Odd squares: a(n) = (2n+1)^2. Also centered octagonal numbers|accessdate=2016-06-11}}</ref>
* 842 = 2 × 421, nontotient
* 843 = 3 × 281, [[Lucas number]]<ref>{{Cite OEIS|1=A000032|2=Lucas numbers|accessdate=2016-06-11}}</ref>
* 844 = 2<sup>2</sup> × 211, nontotient
* 845 = 5 × 13<sup>2</sup>
* 846 = 2 × 3<sup>2</sup> × 47, sum of eight consecutive primes (89 + 97 + 101 + 103 + 107 + 109 + 113 + 127), nontotient, Harshad number
* 847 = 7 × 11<sup>2</sup>, [[happy number]]
* 848 = 2<sup>4</sup> × 53
* 849 = 3 × 283, the Mertens function of 849 returns 0

===850s===
* 850 = 2 × 5<sup>2</sup> × 17, the Mertens function of 850 returns 0, nontotient, the maximum possible [[Credit score (United States)#Range of scores|Fair Isaac credit score]], country calling code for North Korea
* 851 = 23 × 37
* 852 = 2<sup>2</sup> × 3 × 71, [[pentagonal number]],<ref>{{Cite OEIS|1=A000326|2=Pentagonal numbers|accessdate=2016-06-11}}</ref> Smith number<ref name=":3" />
** country calling code for Hong Kong
* 853 = prime number, [[Perrin number]],<ref>{{Cite OEIS|1=A001608|2=Perrin sequence|accessdate=2016-06-11}}</ref> the [[Mertens function]] of 853 returns 0, average of first 853 prime numbers is an integer {{OEIS|id=A045345}}, strictly non-palindromic number, number of connected graphs with 7 nodes
** country calling code for Macau
* 854 = 2 × 7 × 61, nontotient
* 855 = 3<sup>2</sup> × 5 × 19, [[decagonal number]],<ref>{{Cite OEIS|1=A001107|2=10-gonal (or decagonal) numbers|accessdate=2016-06-11}}</ref> [[centered cube number]]<ref>{{Cite OEIS|1=A005898|2=Centered cube numbers|accessdate=2016-06-11}}</ref>
** country calling code for Cambodia
* 856 = 2<sup>3</sup> × 107, [[nonagonal number]],<ref>{{Cite OEIS|1=A001106|2=9-gonal (or enneagonal or nonagonal) numbers|accessdate=2016-06-11}}</ref> [[centered pentagonal number]],<ref>{{Cite OEIS|1=A005891|2=Centered pentagonal numbers|accessdate=2016-06-11}}</ref> [[happy number]]
** country calling code for Laos
* 857 = prime number, sum of three consecutive primes (281 + 283 + 293), Chen prime, Eisenstein prime with no imaginary part
* 858 = 2 × 3 × 11 × 13, [[Giuga number]]<ref>{{Cite OEIS|1=A007850|2=Giuga numbers|accessdate=2016-06-11}}</ref>
* 859 = prime number

===860s===
* 860 = 2<sup>2</sup> × 5 × 43, sum of four consecutive primes (199 + 211 + 223 + 227)
* 861 = 3 × 7 × 41, sphenic number, triangular number,<ref name=":2" /> [[hexagonal number]],<ref>{{Cite OEIS|1=A000384|2=Hexagonal numbers|accessdate=2016-06-11}}</ref> Smith number<ref name=":3" />
* 862 = 2 × 431
* 863 = prime number, safe prime,<ref name=":5" /> sum of five consecutive primes (163 + 167 + 173 + 179 + 181), sum of seven consecutive primes (107 + 109 + 113 + 127 + 131 + 137 + 139), Chen prime, Eisenstein prime with no imaginary part
* 864 = 2<sup>5</sup> × 3<sup>3</sup>, sum of a twin prime (431 + 433), sum of six consecutive primes (131 + 137 + 139 + 149 + 151 + 157), Harshad number
* 865 = 5 × 173,
* 866 = 2 × 433, nontotient
* 867 = 3 × 17<sup>2</sup>
* 868 = 2<sup>2</sup> × 7 × 31, nontotient
* 869 = 11 × 79, the Mertens function of 869 returns 0

===870s===
* 870 = 2 × 3 × 5 × 29, sum of ten consecutive primes (67 + 71 + 73 + 79 + 83 + 89 + 97 + 101 + 103 + 107), pronic number,<ref name=":1" /> nontotient, sparsely totient number,<ref name=":6" /> Harshad number
** This number is the [[magic constant]] of ''n''×''n'' normal [[magic square]] and [[Eight queens puzzle|''n''-queens problem]] for ''n'' = 12.
* 871 = 13 × 67
* 872 = 2<sup>3</sup> × 109, nontotient
* 873 = 3<sup>2</sup> × 97, sum of the first six factorials from 1
* 874 = 2 × 19 × 23, sum of the first twenty-three primes, sum of the first seven factorials from 0, nontotient, Harshad number, [[happy number]]
* 875 = 5<sup>3</sup> × 7
* 876 = 2<sup>2</sup> × 3 × 73
* 877 = prime number, [[Bell number]],<ref>{{Cite OEIS|1=A000110|2=Bell or exponential numbers|accessdate=2016-06-11}}</ref> Chen prime, the Mertens function of 877 returns 0, strictly non-palindromic number.<ref name=":4" />
* 878 = 2 × 439, nontotient
* 879 = 3 × 293

===880s===

{{Main|880 (number)}}
* 880 = 2<sup>4</sup> × 5 × 11, Harshad number; 148-[[polygonal number|gonal number]]; the number of ''n''×''n'' [[magic square]]s for n = 4.
** country calling code for Bangladesh

{{Main|881 (number)}}
* 881 = prime number, [[twin prime]], sum of nine consecutive primes (79 + 83 + 89 + 97 + 101 + 103 + 107 + 109 + 113), Chen prime, Eisenstein prime with no imaginary part, [[happy number]]
* 882 = 2 × 3<sup>2</sup> × 7<sup>2</sup>, Harshad number, totient sum for first 53 integers
* 883 = prime number, [[twin prime]], sum of three consecutive primes (283 + 293 + 307), the  Mertens function of 883 returns 0
* 884 = 2<sup>2</sup> × 13 × 17, the Mertens function of 884 returns 0
* 885 = 3 × 5 × 59, sphenic number
* 886 = 2 × 443, the Mertens function of 886 returns 0
** country calling code for Taiwan
* 887 = prime number followed by primal [[prime gap|gap]] of 20, safe prime,<ref name=":5" /> Chen prime, Eisenstein prime with no imaginary part

{| style="clear: right" align="right"
| [[Image:Seven-segment 8.svg]][[Image:Seven-segment 8.svg]][[Image:Seven-segment 8.svg]]
|}
{{Main|888 (number)}}
* 888 = 2<sup>3</sup> × 3 × 37, sum of eight consecutive primes (97 + 101 + 103 + 107 + 109 + 113 + 127 + 131), Harshad number, [[strobogrammatic number]]<ref name=":0">{{Cite OEIS|1=A000787|2=Strobogrammatic numbers|accessdate=2016-06-11}}</ref>
* 889 = 7 × 127, the Mertens function of 889 returns 0

===890s===
* 890 = 2 × 5 × 89, sphenic number, sum of four consecutive primes (211 + 223 + 227 + 229), nontotient
* 891 = 3<sup>4</sup> × 11, sum of five consecutive primes (167 + 173 + 179 + 181 + 191), [[octahedral number]]
* 892 = 2<sup>2</sup> × 223, nontotient
* 893 = 19 × 47, the Mertens function of 893 returns 0
** Considered an unlucky number in [[Japan]], because its digits read sequentially are the literal translation of ''[[yakuza]]''.
* 894 = 2 × 3 × 149, sphenic number, nontotient
* 895 = 5 × 179, Smith number,<ref name=":3" /> [[Woodall number]],<ref>{{Cite OEIS|1=A003261|2=Woodall numbers|accessdate=2016-06-11}}</ref> the Mertens function of 895 returns 0
* 896 = 2<sup>7</sup> × 7, sum of six consecutive primes (137 + 139 + 149 + 151 + 157 + 163), the Mertens function of 896 returns 0
* 897 = 3 × 13 × 23, sphenic number
* 898 = 2 × 449, the Mertens function of 898 returns 0, nontotient
* 899 = 29 × 31, [[happy number]]

pages.title: 801 (number)
pages.text:
{{Infobox number}}
'''801''' ('''eight hundred [and] one''') is the [[natural number]] following [[800 (number)|800]] and preceding [[800 (number)#800s|802]].

801 is the sum of a square and positive cube in more than one way, and a sum of distinct positive cubes in more than one way:<ref>{{Cite OEIS|sequencenumber=A055393|name=Sum of a square and a nonnegative cube in more than one way}}</ref><ref>{{Cite OEIS|sequencenumber=A003998|name=Numbers that are a sum of distinct positive cubes in more than one way}}</ref>
:<math>801 = 17^2 + 8^3 = 26^2 + 5^3 = 1^3 + 2^3 + 4^3 + 6^3 + 8^3 = 2^3 + 4^3 + 9^3.</math>

In the [[gematria]] of 2nd century bishop [[Irenaeus]], 801 stands for both the [[Greek language|Greek]] word for a dove, and for [[Alpha and Omega]], and therefore represents God in two ways.<ref>{{citation|title=The Greek Qabalah: Alphabetical Mysticism and Numerology in the Ancient World|first=Kieren|last=Barry|publisher=Weiser Books|year=1999|isbn=9781609252274|pages=110–111|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=w70rWN_-ANAC&pg=PA110}}.</ref>

==See also==
*[[801 (disambiguation)]]

pages.title: 836 (number)
pages.text:
{{Infobox number
| number = 836
}}
'''836''' ('''eight hundred [and] thirty-six''') is the [[natural number]] following [[800 (number)#830s|835]] and preceding [[800 (number)#830s|837]].

==In mathematics==
The factorization of 836 is 2<sup>2</sup> × 11 × 19, so its proper factors are 1, 2, 4, 11, 19, 22, 38, 44, 76, 209, and 418. They sum to 844. As this is greater than 836, it is an [[abundant number]], but no subset sums to 836, so it is not a [[semiperfect number]]; therefore it is a [[weird number]].<ref>{{cite web|title=Sloane's A006037 : Weird numbers|url=https://oeis.org/A006037|website=The On-Line Encyclopedia of Integer Sequences|publisher=OEIS Foundation|accessdate=2016-06-02}}</ref> Besides, 836 is the smallest weird number that is also [[untouchable number]], i.e. there is no n such that sum of proper factors of n equals 836. (the only smaller weird number [[70 (number)|70]] is not untouchable, since σ(134)−134=70)

==See also==
* [[836]] (year)
* [[836 Jole]] (asteroid)
* [[836th Air Division]], an inactive United States Air Force organization
* [[836 Naval Air Squadron]], a World War II organization in the British Navy
* [[Pi Arietis]], designated as object 836 in the Bright Star catalogue

==References==
{{Reflist}}

pages.title: 840 (number)
pages.text:
{{Infobox number
| number = 840
| divisor = 1, 2, 3, 4, 5, 6, 7, 8, 10, 12, 14, 15, 20, 21, 24, 28, 30, 35, 40, 42, 56, 60, 70, 84, 105, 120, 140, 168, 210, 280, 420, 840
}}
'''840''' is the [[natural number]] following 839 and preceding 841.

It is a [[highly composite number]],<ref>{{Cite OEIS|A002182|name=Highly composite numbers, definition (1): where d(n), the number of divisors of n (A000005), increases to a record}}</ref>
a [[superabundant number]],<ref>{{Cite OEIS|A004394|name=Superabundant [or super-abundant] numbers: n such that sigma(n)/n > sigma(m)/m for all m<n, sigma(n) being the sum of the divisors of n}}</ref> an [[idoneal number]],<ref>{{Cite OEIS|A000926|name=Euler's "numerus idoneus" (or "numeri idonei", or idoneal, or suitable, or convenient numbers)}}</ref>
and is the [[least common multiple]] of 1, 2, 3, 4, 5, 6, 7, 8.<ref>{{Cite OEIS|A003418|name=Least common multiple (or LCM) of {1, 2, ..., n} for n >= 1}}</ref>

840 is the largest number ''k'' such that all coprime [[Quadratic residue|quadratic residues]] modulo ''k'' are squares. In this case, they are 1, 121, 169, 289, 361 and 529.<ref>{{Cite OEIS|A303704|name=Numbers k such that all coprime quadratic residues modulo k are squares.}}</ref>

[[Category:Integers]]

pages.title: 880 (number)
881 (number)
888 (number)
pages.text:
{{for|the year 888 AD|888}}
{{infobox number
| number        = 888
}}
'''888''' ('''eight hundred [and] eighty-eight''') is the [[natural number]] following [[800 (number)#880s|887]] and preceding [[800 (number)#880s|889]].

==In mathematics==
888 is a [[repdigit]] (a number all of whose digits are equal),<ref>{{Cite OEIS|sequencenumber=A010785|name=Repdigit numbers, or numbers with repeated digits}}</ref> and a [[strobogrammatic number]] (one that reads the same upside-down on a seven-segment calculator display).<ref>{{Cite OEIS|sequencenumber=A018846|name=Strobogrammatic numbers: numbers that are the same upside down (using calculator-style numerals)}}</ref> 888<sup>3</sup> = 700227072 is the smallest [[Cube (algebra)|cube]] in which each digit occurs exactly three times,<ref>{{Cite OEIS|sequencenumber=A052071|name=a(n)^3 is the smallest cube whose digits occur with the same frequency n}}</ref> and the only cube in which three distinct digits each occur three times.<ref>{{citation|title=Number Gossip|first=Tanya|last=Khovanova|year=2008|publisher=Gathering for Gardner|arxiv=0804.2277|url=http://www.tanyakhovanova.com/publications/0804.2277.pdf|bibcode=2008arXiv0804.2277K}}.</ref> 888  the smallest multiple of 24 whose [[digit sum]] is 24,<ref>{{Cite OEIS|sequencenumber=A002998|name=Smallest multiple of n whose digits sum to n}}</ref> and as well as being divisible by its digit sum it is divisible by all of its digits.<ref>{{Cite OEIS|sequencenumber=A051004|name=Numbers divisible both by their individual digits and by the sum of their digits}}</ref>

888 is a [[practical number]], meaning that every positive integer up to 888 itself may be represented as a sum of distinct [[divisor]]s of 888.<ref>[http://jean-paul.davalan.pagesperso-orange.fr/arit/pract/practicalsnumbers.html Nombres pratiques] (in French), Jeux et Mathématiques, Jean-Paul Davalan, retrieved 2013-01-31.</ref>

There are exactly 888 [[tree (mathematics)|trees]] with four unlabeled and three labeled nodes,<ref>{{Cite OEIS|sequencenumber=A000269|name=Number of trees with n nodes, 3 of which are labeled}}</ref> exactly 888 seven-node [[undirected graph]]s without isolated vertices,<ref>{{Cite OEIS|sequencenumber=A002494|name=Number of n-node graphs without isolated nodes}}</ref> and exactly 888 [[Alternating knot|non-alternating knots]] whose [[Crossing number (knot theory)|crossing number]] is 12.<ref>{{Cite OEIS|sequencenumber=A051763|name=Number of nonalternating knots with n crossings}}</ref>

==Symbology and numerology==
In [[Christianity|Christian]] [[numerology]], the number 888 represents [[Jesus]], or sometimes more specifically Christ the Redeemer. This representation may be justified either through [[gematria]], by counting the letter values of the [[Greek alphabet|Greek]] transliteration of Jesus' name,<ref>{{citation|title=Numerology: Or What Pythagoras Wrought|series=[[Mathematical Association of America|MAA]] Spectrum|first=Underwood|last=Dudley|authorlink=Underwood Dudley|publisher=Cambridge University Press|year=1997|isbn=9780883855249|page=105|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=udptayxY2E8C&pg=PA105}}.</ref> or as an opposing value to [[666 (number)|666]], the [[number of the beast]].<ref>{{citation|title=Book Of Fate And Fortune: Numerology And Astrology|author=[[Cheiro]]|publisher=Orient Paperbacks|year=2005|isbn=9788122200461|page=60|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=464XH0LOCEgC&pg=PA60}}.</ref>

In [[Numbers in Chinese culture|Chinese numerology]], 888 has a different meaning, triple fortune, a strengthening of the meaning of the digit 8.<ref>{{citation|title=Understanding Information Systems: What They Do and Why We Need Them|first=Lee|last=Ratzan|publisher=American Library Association|year=2004|isbn=9780838908686|page=202|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=lrdRYCRjUZUC&pg=PA202}}.</ref> For this reason, addresses and phone numbers containing the digit sequence 888 are considered particularly lucky, and may command a premium because of it.<ref>{{citation|title=Working Across Cultures|first=John|last=Hooker|publisher=Stanford University Press|year=2003|isbn=9780804748070|page=191|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=wJXo_mOXd1IC&pg=PA191}}.</ref>

==See also==
* [[888 (disambiguation)]]
