pages.title: 900 (number)
pages.text:
{{For|the year 900|900 BC|900 AD}}
{{Infobox number
| number = 900
| divisor = 1, 2, 3, 4, 5, 6, 9, 10, 12, 15, 18, 20, 25, 30, 36, 45, 50, 60, 75, 90, 100, 150, 180, 225, 300, 450, 900
| unicode = CM, cm
}}
'''900''' ('''nine hundred''') is the [[natural number]] following [[899 (number)|899]] and preceding [[901 (number)|901]]. It is the square of [[30 (number)|30]] and the sum of [[Euler's totient function]] for the first 54 integers. In base 10 it is a [[Harshad number]].

==In other fields==
'''900''' is also:

* A telephone [[area code]] for [[premium rate telephone number|"premium" phone calls]] in the [[North American Numbering Plan]]
* In Greek [[Greek numerals|number symbols]], the sign [[Sampi]] ("ϡ", literally "like a [[Pi]]")
* A [[900 (skateboarding trick)|skateboarding trick]] in which the skateboarder spins two and a half times (360 degrees times 2.5 is 900)
* A [[900_series_(bowling)|900 series]] refers to three consecutive [[Perfect_game_(bowling)|perfect games]] in [[bowling]]

==Integers from 901 to 999==

===900s===
* 901 = 17 × 53, [[happy number]]
* 902 = 2 × 11 × 41, [[sphenic number]], [[nontotient]], Harshad number
* 903 = 3 × 7 × 43, sphenic number, triangular number,<ref name=":0">{{Cite web|url=https://oeis.org/A000217|title=Sloane's A000217 : Triangular numbers|website=The On-Line Encyclopedia of Integer Sequences|publisher=OEIS Foundation|access-date=2016-06-11}}</ref> [[Schröder–Hipparchus number]], [[Mertens function]] (903) returns 0
* 904 = 2<sup>3</sup> × 113 or 113 × 8, Mertens function(904) returns 0
* 905 = 5 × 181, sum of seven consecutive primes (109 + 113 + 127 + 131 + 137 + 139 + 149)
** "The 905" is [[Area codes 905, 289 and 365#905 in popular culture|a common nickname]] for the suburban portions of the [[Greater Toronto Area]] in Canada, a region whose telephones used [[Area codes 905, 289 and 365|area code 905]] before [[overlay plan]]s added two more area codes.
* 906 = 2 × 3 × 151, sphenic number, Mertens function(906) returns 0
* 907 = prime number
* 908 = 2<sup>2</sup> × 227, nontotient
* 909 = 3<sup>2</sup> × 101

===910s===
* 910 = 2 × 5 × 7 × 13, Mertens function(910) returns 0, Harshad number, [[happy number]]
* [[911 (number)|911]] = prime number, also the [[9-1-1|emergency telephone number]] in [[North America]]
* 912 = 2<sup>4</sup> × 3 × 19, sum of four consecutive primes (223 + 227 + 229 + 233), sum of ten consecutive primes (71 + 73 + 79 + 83 + 89 + 97 + 101 + 103 + 107 + 109), Harshad number. 
* 913 = 11 × 83, [[Smith number]],<ref name=":1">{{Cite web|url=https://oeis.org/A006753|title=Sloane's A006753 : Smith numbers|website=The On-Line Encyclopedia of Integer Sequences|publisher=OEIS Foundation|access-date=2016-06-11}}</ref> Mertens function(913) returns 0. 
* 914 = 2 × 457, nontotient
* 915 = 3 × 5 × 61, sphenic number, Smith number,<ref name=":1" /> Mertens function(915) returns 0, Harshad number
* 916 = 2<sup>2</sup> × 229, Mertens function(916) returns 0, nontotient, member of the [[Mian–Chowla sequence]]<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://oeis.org/A005282|title=Sloane's A005282 : Mian-Chowla sequence|website=The On-Line Encyclopedia of Integer Sequences|publisher=OEIS Foundation|access-date=2016-06-11}}</ref>
* 917 = 7 × 131, sum of five consecutive primes (173 + 179 + 181 + 191 + 193)
* 918 = 2 × 3<sup>3</sup> × 17, Harshad number
* 919 = prime number, [[cuban prime]],<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://oeis.org/A002407|title=Sloane's A002407 : Cuban primes|website=The On-Line Encyclopedia of Integer Sequences|publisher=OEIS Foundation|access-date=2016-06-11}}</ref> [[Chen prime]], [[palindromic prime]], [[centered hexagonal number]],<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://oeis.org/A003215|title=Sloane's A003215 : Hex (or centered hexagonal) numbers|website=The On-Line Encyclopedia of Integer Sequences|publisher=OEIS Foundation|access-date=2016-06-11}}</ref> [[happy number]], Mertens function(919) returns 0

===920s===
* 920 = 2<sup>3</sup> × 5 × 23, Mertens function(920) returns 0
* 921 = 3 × 307
* 922 = 2 × 461, nontotient, Smith number<ref name=":1" />
* 923 = 13 × 71
* 924 = 2<sup>2</sup> × 3 × 7 × 11, sum of a twin prime (461 + 463), [[central binomial coefficient]] <math>\tbinom {12} 6</math><ref>{{Cite web|url=https://oeis.org/A000984|title=Sloane's A000984 : Central binomial coefficients|website=The On-Line Encyclopedia of Integer Sequences|publisher=OEIS Foundation|access-date=2016-06-11}}</ref>
* 925 = 5<sup>2</sup> × 37, [[pentagonal number]],<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://oeis.org/A000326|title=Sloane's A000326 : Pentagonal numbers|website=The On-Line Encyclopedia of Integer Sequences|publisher=OEIS Foundation|access-date=2016-06-11}}</ref> [[centered square number]]<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://oeis.org/A001844|title=Sloane's A001844 : Centered square numbers|website=The On-Line Encyclopedia of Integer Sequences|publisher=OEIS Foundation|access-date=2016-06-11}}</ref>
** The [[millesimal fineness]] number for [[Sterling silver]]
* 926 = 2 × 463, sum of six consecutive primes (139 + 149 + 151 + 157 + 163 + 167), nontotient
* 927 = 3<sup>2</sup> × 103, [[tribonacci number]]<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://oeis.org/A000073|title=Sloane's A000073 : Tribonacci numbers|website=The On-Line Encyclopedia of Integer Sequences|publisher=OEIS Foundation|access-date=2016-06-11}}</ref>
* 928 = 2<sup>5</sup> × 29, sum of four consecutive primes (227 + 229 + 233 + 239), sum of eight consecutive primes (101 + 103 + 107 + 109 + 113 + 127 + 131 + 137), [[happy number]]
* 929 = prime number, [[Proth prime]],<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://oeis.org/A080076|title=Sloane's A080076 : Proth primes|website=The On-Line Encyclopedia of Integer Sequences|publisher=OEIS Foundation|access-date=2016-06-11}}</ref> palindromic prime, sum of nine consecutive primes (83 + 89 + 97 + 101 + 103 + 107 + 109 + 113 + 127), [[Eisenstein prime]] with no imaginary part
** An [[Area code 929|area code in New York]].

===930s===
* 930 = 2 × 3 × 5 × 31, [[pronic number]]<ref name=":2">{{Cite web|url=https://oeis.org/A002378|title=Sloane's A002378 : Oblong (or promic, pronic, or heteromecic) numbers|website=The On-Line Encyclopedia of Integer Sequences|publisher=OEIS Foundation|access-date=2016-06-11}}</ref>
* 931 = 7<sup>2</sup> × 19; sum of three consecutive primes (307 + 311 + 313); double [[repdigit]], 111<sub>30</sub> and 777<sub>11</sub>
* 932 = 2<sup>2</sup> × 233
* 933 = 3 × 311
* 934 = 2 × 467, nontotient
* 935 = 5 × 11 × 17, sphenic number, [[Lucas–Carmichael number]],<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://oeis.org/A006972|title=Sloane's A006972 : Lucas-Carmichael numbers|website=The On-Line Encyclopedia of Integer Sequences|publisher=OEIS Foundation|access-date=2016-06-11}}</ref> Harshad number
* 936 = 2<sup>3</sup> × 3<sup>2</sup> × 13, [[pentagonal pyramidal number]],<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://oeis.org/A002411|title=Sloane's A002411 : Pentagonal pyramidal numbers|website=The On-Line Encyclopedia of Integer Sequences|publisher=OEIS Foundation|access-date=2016-06-11}}</ref> Harshad number
* 937 = prime number, Chen prime, [[star number]],<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://oeis.org/A003154|title=Sloane's A003154 : Centered 12-gonal numbers. Also star numbers|website=The On-Line Encyclopedia of Integer Sequences|publisher=OEIS Foundation|access-date=2016-06-11}}</ref> [[happy number]]
* 938 = 2 × 7 × 67, sphenic number, nontotient
* 939 = 3 × 313

===940s===
* 940 = 2<sup>2</sup> × 5 × 47, totient sum for first 55 integers
* 941 = prime number, sum of three consecutive primes (311 + 313 + 317), sum of five consecutive primes (179 + 181 + 191 + 193 + 197), Chen prime, Eisenstein prime with no imaginary part
* 942 = 2 × 3 × 157, sphenic number, sum of four consecutive primes (229 + 233 + 239 + 241), nontotient
* 943 = 23 × 41
* 944 = 2<sup>4</sup> × 59, nontotient
* 945 = 3<sup>3</sup> × 5 × 7, [[double factorial]] of [[9 (number)|9]],<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://oeis.org/A006882|title=Sloane's A006882 : Double factorials|website=The On-Line Encyclopedia of Integer Sequences|publisher=OEIS Foundation|access-date=2016-06-11}}</ref> smallest odd [[abundant number]] (divisors less than itself add up to 975);<ref>{{cite book |title=Number Story: From Counting to Cryptography |last=Higgins |first=Peter |year=2008 |publisher=Copernicus |location=New York |isbn=978-1-84800-000-1 |page=13 |pages= }}</ref> smallest odd [[primitive abundant number]];<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://oeis.org/A006038|title=Sloane's A006038 : Odd primitive abundant numbers|website=The On-Line Encyclopedia of Integer Sequences|publisher=OEIS Foundation|access-date=2016-06-11}}</ref> smallest odd [[primitive semiperfect number]];<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://oeis.org/A006036|title=Sloane's A006036 : Primitive pseudoperfect numbers|website=The On-Line Encyclopedia of Integer Sequences|publisher=OEIS Foundation|access-date=2016-06-11}}</ref> [[Leyland number]]<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://oeis.org/A076980|title=Sloane's A076980 : Leyland numbers|website=The On-Line Encyclopedia of Integer Sequences|publisher=OEIS Foundation|access-date=2016-06-11}}</ref>
* 946 = 2 × 11 × 43, sphenic number, triangular number,<ref name=":0" /> [[hexagonal number]],<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://oeis.org/A000384|title=Sloane's A000384 : Hexagonal numbers|website=The On-Line Encyclopedia of Integer Sequences|publisher=OEIS Foundation|access-date=2016-06-11}}</ref> [[happy number]]
* 947 = prime number, sum of seven consecutive primes (113 + 127 + 131 + 137 + 139 + 149 + 151), [[balanced prime]],<ref name=":3">{{Cite web|url=https://oeis.org/A006562|title=Sloane's A006562 : Balanced primes|website=The On-Line Encyclopedia of Integer Sequences|publisher=OEIS Foundation|access-date=2016-06-11}}</ref> Chen prime, Eisenstein prime with no imaginary part
* 948 = 2<sup>2</sup> × 3 × 79, nontotient, forms a [[Ruth–Aaron pair]] with 949 under second definition
* 949 = 13 × 73, forms a Ruth–Aaron pair with 948 under second definition

===950s===
* 950 = 2 × 5<sup>2</sup> × 19, nontotient
** one of two [[ISBN]] Group Identifiers for books published in [[Argentina]]
* 951 = 3 × 317, [[centered pentagonal number]]<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://oeis.org/A005891|title=Sloane's A005891 : Centered pentagonal numbers|website=The On-Line Encyclopedia of Integer Sequences|publisher=OEIS Foundation|access-date=2016-06-11}}</ref>
** one of two ISBN Group Identifiers for books published in [[Finland]]
* 952 = 2<sup>3</sup> × 7 × 17
** 952 is also ''[[9-5-2]],'' a [[card game]] similar to [[Contract bridge|bridge]].
** one of two ISBN Group Identifiers for books published in [[Finland]]
* 953 = prime number, Sophie Germain prime,<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://oeis.org/A005384|title=Sloane's A005384 : Sophie Germain primes|website=The On-Line Encyclopedia of Integer Sequences|publisher=OEIS Foundation|access-date=2016-06-11}}</ref> Chen prime, Eisenstein prime with no imaginary part, [[centered heptagonal number]]<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://oeis.org/A069099|title=Sloane's A069099 : Centered heptagonal numbers|website=The On-Line Encyclopedia of Integer Sequences|publisher=OEIS Foundation|access-date=2016-06-11}}</ref>
** ISBN Group Identifier for books published in [[Croatia]]
* 954 = 2 × 3<sup>2</sup> × 53, sum of ten consecutive primes (73 + 79 + 83 + 89 + 97 + 101 + 103 + 107 + 109 + 113), nontotient, Harshad number
** ISBN Group Identifier for books published in [[Bulgaria]]. Also one of the [[Area code 954|Area Codes]] in the [[South Florida metropolitan area|South Florida]] Area
* 955 = 5 × 191
** ISBN Group Identifier for books published in [[Sri Lanka]]
* 956 = 2<sup>2</sup> × 239
** ISBN Group Identifier for books published in [[Chile]]
* 957 = 3 × 11 × 29, sphenic number
** one of two ISBN Group Identifiers for books published in [[Taiwan]] and [[China]]
* 958 = 2 × 479, nontotient, Smith number<ref name=":1" />
** ISBN Group Identifier for books published in [[Colombia]]
** The [[millesimal fineness]] number for [[Britannia silver]]
* 959 = 7 × 137, [[Carol number]]<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://oeis.org/A093112|title=Sloane's A093112 : a(n) = (2^n-1)^2 - 2|website=The On-Line Encyclopedia of Integer Sequences|publisher=OEIS Foundation|access-date=2016-06-11}}</ref>
** ISBN Group Identifier for books published in [[Cuba]]

===960s===
* 960 = 2<sup>6</sup> × 3 × 5, sum of six consecutive primes (149 + 151 + 157 + 163 + 167 + 173), Harshad number
** country calling code for Maldives, ISBN Group Identifier for books published in [[Greece]]
** The number of possible starting positions for the [[List of chess variants|chess variant]] [[Chess960]]
*** Chess960 also got its name from the number itself
* 961 = 31<sup>2</sup>, the largest 3-digit perfect square, sum of three consecutive primes (313 + 317 + 331), sum of five consecutive primes (181 + 191 + 193 + 197 + 199), [[centered octagonal number]]<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://oeis.org/A016754|title=Sloane's A016754 : Odd squares: a(n) = (2n+1)^2. Also centered octagonal numbers|website=The On-Line Encyclopedia of Integer Sequences|publisher=OEIS Foundation|access-date=2016-06-11}}</ref>
** country calling code for Lebanon, ISBN Group Identifier for books published in [[Slovenia]]
* 962 = 2 × 13 × 37, sphenic number, nontotient
** country calling code for Jordan, one of two ISBN Group Identifiers for books published in [[Hong Kong]]
* 963 = 3<sup>2</sup> × 107, sum of the first twenty-four primes
** country calling code for Syria, ISBN Group Identifier for books published in [[Hungary]]
* 964 = 2<sup>2</sup> × 241, sum of four consecutive primes (233 + 239 + 241 + 251), nontotient, totient sum for first 56 integers
** country calling code for Iraq, ISBN Group Identifier for books published in [[Iran]], [[happy number]]
* 965 = 5 × 193
** country calling code for Kuwait, ISBN Group Identifier for books published in [[Israel]]

** country calling code for Mongolia, ISBN Group Identifier for books published in [[Antigua]], [[Bahamas]], [[Barbados]], [[Belize]], [[Cayman Islands]], [[Dominica]], [[Grenada]], [[Guyana]], [[Jamaica]], [[Montserrat]], [[Saint Kitts and Nevis]], [[St. Lucia]], [[Saint Vincent and the Grenadines|St. Vincent and the Grenadines]], [[Trinidad and Tobago]], and the [[British Virgin Islands]]

* 999 = 3<sup>3</sup> × 37, [[Kaprekar number]], Harshad number

** '''[[999 (band)|999]]''' was a [[London]] [[punk rock|punk]] band active during the 1970s.

pages.title: 911 (number)
971 (number)
pages.text:
{{Infobox number}}
'''971''' ('''nine hundred seventy one''') is the [[natural number]] following [[970 (number)|970]] and preceding [[972 (number)|972]].

971 is a [[prime number]], a [[Chen prime]] and an [[Eisenstein prime]].

Some uses of 971:
*+971, the country calling code for [[telephone numbers in the United Arab Emirates]]
*[[Area code 971]], for telephone numbers in northwestern Oregon
*One of the [[List of ISBN identifier groups|ISBN identifier groups]] for books published in the Philippines


==U.S. state highways==
As a U.S. state route or highway, '''971''' may refer to:
*[[Louisiana Highway 971]]
*[[Washington State Route 971]]
*[[West Virginia Route 971]]
[[File:Circle sign 971.svg|100px|right]]


==External links==
* [http://www.wolframalpha.com/input/?i=971 971] at [[Wolfram Alpha]]

'''999''' ('''nine hundred ninety-nine''' or '''nine-nine-nine''') is a [[natural number]] following [[998 (number)|998]] and preceding [[1000 (number)|1000]].{{Infobox number
| number = 999
| cardinal = Nine hundred [and] ninety-nine
| ordinal text = Nine hundred [and] ninety-ninth
| divisor = 1, 3, 9, 27, 37, 111, 333, 999
| unicode = 
| greek prefix = 
| latin prefix = 
}}

==In mathematics==
* a [[Harshad number]].
* a [[Kaprekar number]].<ref>{{cite web|title=Sloane's A006886 : Kaprekar numbers|url=https://oeis.org/A006886|website=The On-Line Encyclopedia of Integer Sequences|publisher=OEIS Foundation|accessdate=2016-06-02}}</ref>
* a [[repdigit]] in bases 10 and 36.
* a [[palindromic number]] in bases 10, 14 (515<sub>14</sub>), and 36 (RR<sub>36</sub>).
* the largest 3-digit [[decimal]] [[integer]].

==Symbology and numerology==
In [[SubGenius]] [[numerology]] the number 999 represents [[Bob Dobbs]].

==Emergency Number==
'''999''' is the number used to contact the Emergency Services in many countries; See [[999 (emergency telephone number)]].
